Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill concurrently with the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The legislation concerns the wine section of the broader grape industry· of Australia. The grape industry is very complex because it has different elements. There are grapes for dried vine fruit-raisins, sultanas, et cetera-there are grapes for wine, particularly the premium varieties which are for wine only, and some of the other varieties which can have one of a number of ultimate uses-dried fruit, fresh fruit or wine-and then there is the fresh table grapes section, which has had some volatility in its rapid development but which generally has great potential for exports and is second to the packham pear as a fresh fruit export of this country. In addition to that complexity and volatility that there is in this movement of certain grapes from one end use to another, the report of the Industries Assistance Commission has caused considerable concern in the dried vine fruit section of the industry. If the report is adopted by the Government, more grapes of certain varieties could be forced into wine production but at the bulk end of the wine production scale, which is the declining sector. It is not the way for the Australian wine industry to go in the future and it is not the way the industry itself wants to go. The production for wine adds to the total volatile mix. In the season just completed, production of grapes for wine making reached 554,000 tonnes, an increase of over 20 per cent on the previous year. That dramatic increase in production comes at a time when domestic sales have declined by almost 7 per cent. BILL 1989 Increased costs have led to higher prices and the demand for lower priced soft-pack wine has decreased, as has the demand for brandy, fortified wine, and some other types of wine, 1989) but generally bottled wine sales have increased. The dramatic increase in exports evident in 1986-87 and 1987-88 has slowed this year when our total exports of 40 million litres are worth $1l3m. However, the value of those exports has increased from $97m to $1l3m, or 15 per cent, even though the increase in volume was only 3 per cent. The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation believes that export markets hold the key to future industry growth and prosperity and the Corporation is undertaking a detailed and intense analysis to help with future promotion and market development. Substantial production increases are projected for a number of premium varieties over the next couple of years, .some of which are as high as 40 per cent. Everyone connected with the industry acknowledges that there is considerable potential to increase exports from the one per cent share of the world export market that Australia now has. That potential exists because of the high and stable quality of Australian wine and its relatively low cost. The industry acknowledges that the export promotion program for wine was materially assisted with a grant of $100,000 from Austrade. The ongoing objective for the industry and the Corporation is the protection and further development of the good name of Australian wine. The Bills which we are debating today, and which the Opposition parties support, are a progressive step in ensuring that the good name and further development of Australian wine are enhanced. The Grape Research Levy Collection Act 1986 allows for a collection of research levies and the industry has agreed that the current rate should be increased. At the moment the maximum rate of the levy is SOc a tonne on grape!! and grape juice. The Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill proposes to lift the levy to $2 a tonne. This will allow a phased increase in the operative level-that is, actual level-of the levy by regulation. That will be done at the request of and in consulwill tation with the industry. That is part of the Government's program of approving the doltage, lar for dollar research arrangements with various primary industries up to a level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of that commodity and it is in line with the policy which the previous coalition Governconsumer ment had and which the next coalition govlabel ernment will have. Therefore it is a very stable policy which will encourage further research and development in the very imporlabels tant primary industries of Australia and will encourage them to develop their export potential. The Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill will will allow the levy which provides the for the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to be restructured to make it fairer and to provide more funds for marketing. Hunter. The levy is imposed on a range of grapes and grape juice used for wine manufacture and it has two components: a marketing amount to finance the Corporation and a discussions research amount for wine research. The levy is payable by winery proprietors using the equivalent of 20 tonnes or more of fresh grapes a year. It is proposed that this amount be reduced to 10 tonnes. At the moment the marketing component is a flat rate of $4 a tonne with a cap, maximum, of $20,000 per levy payer. This has led to smaller and medium sized wineries paying more than their share. For example, a winery crushing 5,000 tonnes pays $20,000 and a bigger winery crushing 80,000 tonnes also pays $20,000. The ceiling has also led to corporate amalgamations to reduce the levy. The ceiling is to be abolished and a gether. tiered levy system introduced with a sliding scale of rates with progressively lower rates as tonnage increases. The levy to fund Corporation will be a flat $200 for each levy payer plus an additional amount depending on the tonnage of grapes used in wine makThis ing. The new arrangements will raise about $750,000 this year and about $1.15m theretimes after. The most interesting concept of the package of legislation is the wine label integrity program that will be introduced by way of the the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. The integrity program require wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vinvariety or region of origin of wine and to make those records and the stocks to which they relate available for audit by the Corporation. The reason for auditing is to ensure truth in labelling which will increase confidence in the reliability of wine claims. Sometimes when one visits wine areas or attends certain functions one hears the statements: 'There are more chardonnay on bottles than there are chardonnay it grapes capable of producing chardonnay' and 'More wine is claimed to have been produced in the Hunter Valley than it is possible to produce'. The integrity program will increase consumer confidence, whether on the domestic market or on the export market. This program was developed by the Corporation in conjunction with the wine industry. It has the support of each of the three national or wine maker organisations. Its adoption was supported by a substantial majority of votes cast at the Corporation's annual meeting early this year. I believe that in total we have a positive package. I commend various elements of the wine industry for developing and proposing this package, and the Government and the Department for putting it toI will make one comment on taxation and the wine industry. Over the years the wine the industry has suffered from changes to the taxation regime relating to wine for maturation, excise versus sales tax and so forth. has created an understandable feeling of insecurity in the industry, and at various an inability to plan properly for the type of wine, particularly the better quality wine. There has been a continuing debate within the industry, between the industry and the Government and, for that matter, within the Opposition parties as to what is a correct and stable taxation regime for the wine industry. The point that the wine industry makes above all other aspects of the debate is that it wants stability in taxation so that it knows what it has to face and can plan accordingly. Many people in the industry would make that plea about taxation to the Government. The industry would like to know whether the present taxation regime will continue so that it can make investment plans accordingly. Two particular aspects of taxation of the wine industry have caused concern: one is the taxing on stock valuation, which has had a negative impact on the premium end of the market, and the other is an inappropriate designation by the Australian Taxation Office of depreciation on oak casks. The industry has been lobbying-the Opposition has been helping with this lobbying-the Government to look again at the depreciation allowance for oak casks. At present, they depreciate over a lO-year period. The wine industry maintains that the effective life of an oak cask for imparting the unique flavour to quality wines is less than three years. Because the depreciation for taxation is over 10 years, vignerons are reluctant to put more wine into oak to produce top quality wine. They also say that oak casks are used not merely for storage; they are used to affect the flavour and aroma by imparting oak flavour and tannin to it. After about three years, that cask will not impart these flavours. The casks can then be used only for storage rather than as an ingredient for wine making. At that stage, they are not even an effective storage system because of their size, so many are sold as flower pots. Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: ln this debate on the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill, I am sure that we can all forgive the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) for the measure of parochialism he has shown, particularly in view of the fact that we are told that he has an audience in the gallery from his electorate. In fact, I suspect that within this House one would find that there are members around who claim to represent wine-making electorates and who claim to represent winemakers whose wine is without peer. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) shakes his head. I am not sure whether he does so to indicate that he does not have any wine manufacturers in his electorate or whether he regrets the fact that he does not have any whom he is able to represent. But I have no doubt that whether a member comes from the electorate of Hunter, Mayo, Barker, MCEwen, Casey, Indi, Wakefield, Adelaide, Gilmore or Curtin he would have an opinion about which is or is not the appropriate wine for a particular meal. The legislation before the House deals very much with the reputation of the Australian wine industry. I acknowledge the wine industry's role in ensuring that it has a reputation as a quality winemaker and its enthusiasm in getting the Government to put into place legislation that would underscore what the industry is already trying to achieve itself. For example, 18 months ago the industry set up a wine industry forum under the chairmanship of Mr Brian Croser, a-South Australian, who happens to live in the electorate of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). Mr Croser, commenting on the forum and writing an article in July 1988, expressed his concern that, in labelling integrity, the Australian wine industry should have a higher profile. The wine industry forum-this body of which Mr Croser is the president-was set up entirely by the industry to ensure that the industry's image was enhanced. The industry is as concerned as any other Australian primary industry, more so than many, about the risk of being blamed for the quite intolerable alcohol abuse in our community. It is not in the interest of the wine industry nor in the interest of society for alcohol abuse to continue. The wine industry forum has been anxious to ensure that the question of integrity can be applied to the wine industry across the spectrum of its activities. I note, for example, that while Australians are regarded by world standards as being relatively high consumers of alcoholic beverages, we consume only 25 per cent per capita of the wine that the French, the Italians and the Portuguese consume. So it is probably fair for the forum and for the wine industry generally to endeavour to separate wine and its impact in the community from the impact in the community of other alcoholic beverages. Mr Croser and his forum have endeavoured to emphasise advantages that the community may find from the responsible consumption of wine. The legislation before the House this morning fits in with the objectives of the wine industry forum. The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill is set up, as the honourable member for Hunter and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) have stressed, to look at integrity in wine labelling, to ensure some form of real consumer protection. We are dealing with two other Bills at the same time: one allows for the equitable collection of a levy to fund the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and the other allows for the collection of additional research funds to enable effective research into grape growing and winemaking in Australia. The wine industry has seen some dramatic, changes over the past six or eight years. In 1988-89, domestic sales of wine were down by 22.3 million litres on the figures for the previous year-a fall of 8.8 per cent. Conversely, export sales of wine were up by 1.3 million litres-an increase of 3.2 per cent. This resulted in a 5.7 per cent fall overall in export and domestic markets for Australian wine. A great deal of optimism has been placed in the export industry as to the direction for Australian winemakers to take, and as a technique by which winemakers may play a role in addressing our present disastrous balance of payments deficit. In 198687 and 1987-88 the export of Australian wine increased by 84 per cent. In 1988-89, possibly because of our rising dollar, there has been a restricted increase of only 3.4 per cent. The most dramatic increase, because it comes from a very narrow base, has, been in the export of Australian champagne. The overall growth in that sector has been 109 per cent, although, as I said, it is from a very small base, which means that champagne still accounts for only 3.5 per cent of total wine industry exports. Of all Australian export industries-and it is probably fair to say, of all Australian primary export industries-the wine industry relies most on consumer confidence and on the faith the consumer places in the labelling on the bottle. The industry is built entirely on reputation. Whether in Australia or overseas, if a wine purchaser chooses a bottle of wine, he or she invariably chooses it with a view to cellaring it. So, it may well be f04r, five or six years before that bottle of wine, particularly in the case of red wine, is consumed. When after five or six years they take the cork out of the bottle, they cannot very well rush back to the wine wholesaler and claim their money back if they are dissatisfied. Consumers depend very much on the wine industry's reputation when they purchase a bottle of wine, whether it is for immediate consumption or for cellaring. For this reason the Opposition supports the Government, as does the wine industry, in the introduction of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. This Bill is designed entirely to enhance the reputation of the Australian wine industry. When I was preparing my comments for this morning 1 noted that one James Russell Lowell, reflecting on the word 'reputation', ,said that a man's-and, I suppose, an industry's-reputation is only a candle, of a wavering and uncertain flame, and easily blown out. But it is the light by which the world looks for and finds merit. I think the Governmentrecognises that the reputatiori of any industry is very fragile, but that same fragile reputation is, in marketing terms, the light by which a market may be opened up. In his second reading contribution the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) made the point that the introduction of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill is principally to increase consumer confidence in the reliability of the claims made on a wine label and enhance the reputation for quality and value of Australian wine in domestic and export markets. The Opposition believes that this enhanced reputation is the key to a successful future for the Australian wine industry, so we are pleased to support the legislation. The other point that needs to be made is that the Australian wine industry currently holds 97 per cent of the domestic market for wine. We will continue to hold that proportion of the domestic market only while we continue to hold the confidence of Australian domestic consumers. Every consumer knows that the price which a winemaker can command for a premium domestic wine makes it attractive for unscrupulous people to be less than honest in their labelling. In fact, so concerned is the industry about this it has been prepared to put in place some form of self-regulation. The knowledge that this self-regulation is now being backed by government legislation, which will allow detection of breaches, will be a strong deterrent to anyone who chooses to abuse the present system. ' There are two other Bil1s before the House: the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill and a Bill to allow for the financing of the Australian Wine Corporation in a more equitable manner. I believe that the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill, which provides the funds that the Corporation needs, fits in very much with the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill, which will provide for integrity in labelling and ensure that winemakers and purchasers can be sure that the labelling on a bottle of wine reflects its contents. What must be appreciated about the Corporation, which will be funded principally by the legislation before the House, is that it has been largely responsible for servicing the increase in exports and in providing facilities for the promotion of Australian wine overseas. Australian wine exports have increased from $20.5m in 1985-86 to an estimated $133m in export earnings this financial year. This is a five-fold increase in the export earnings of Australian wine. The Corporation, which has helped to foster this increase in export earnings, has also been concerned to see that the legislation before the House ensuring that labelling is accurate is in _place. The Corporation has had a real interest in promoting accurate labelling, and one of the Bills we are debating this morning will provide the funds for the Corporation to do its job and promote export earnings. As the honourable member for Murray said, the Corporation is currently funded by a flat rate of $4 a tonne with a cap of $20,000 per levy payer. The Bill before the House allows this to be changed because, under the present legislation; a winery crushing 5,000 tonnes pays $20,000 in levy fees and a larger winery crushing 80,000 tonnes also pays $20,000 in levy fees. The ceiling is to be abolished to ensure that the contribution that wineries make to the Corporation-and the contribution that the Corporation can therefore make to export earnings-reflects more accurately the tonnage crushed by the winery. We endorse that because ,we believe it is a more equitable way to go about raising funds for the Corporation. The third Bill before the House is the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill, which would increase the maximum rate of levy that may be imposed for grape research. As has been the case with a number of other Bills debated in the House this week, this is part of the Government's objective to increase the contribution that industries make towards their own research, by matching the government dollar for dollar up to 0.5 per cent of the total income of that industry. Currently, the maximum rate of levy that the wine grapes industry makes to grape research is 50¢ per tonne. The legislation before the House would increase this to $2 per tonne, which would mean that, whereas in the financial year 1987-88 something like $270,000 was made available for wine grapes research, in the current year up to $520,000 could be made available for wine grapes research. The wine grape industry is a complex industry. It covers wine grapes, dried grapes, fresh grapes and grape juice. The honourable member for Murray has alluded to its complexity. But it has an additional complication; any grapes used specifically for drying, grape juice, wine and as fresh grapes, can also be used for anyone of the other purposes. Any impact of the Government's legislation on the wine grape industry will also have repercussions for the dried fruit and fresh fruit industries. It is, therefore, a complex exercise to find legislation that is appropriate for the grape industry because, if the wine industry is down, the dried fruit industry will be similarly affected. As every wine grape grower can tell us, if the dried fruit industry is adversely affected-for example by the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission report currently being considered by the Government-the fall in dried vine fruit prices will have repercussions for wine grape growers. I conclude by echoing some of the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for Murray. He expressed the concern that the Opposition-and, I believe, the Government-has had to ensure that the Treasury applies a tax rate on maturing stocks of wine that does not deter people from maturing wine. I opened my speech by referring to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill; a Bill designed to ensure that the reputation of the Australian wine industry is enhanced. Unless we encourage winemakers to lay down stocks and mature wines and to make a quality product, our well-intentioned exercise in ensuring that belling reflects what is in the bottle will largely be wasted. In order to enhance the integrity of the Australian wine industry we must also encourage winemakers to make a quality product. The Opposition will always support the Government when its objective is to ensure that what Australians are exporting will do their reputation good.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: 1 welcome the constructive comments of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and I find myself in agreement with the majority of what he has said. I note his support for a progressive levy on the wine industry and I hope that he follows that through to a progressive taxation system and continues to support a progressive taxation system. It is appropriate that I join the debate today, as the Victorian Wine Show was held in Seymour only last Saturday. This is the ninth year of the Victorian Wine Show, which was started by the Seymour Agricultural Society to promote Victorian wine. As most people realise, Victoria was the . largest ducer of wine in Australia until the grapes were devastated by phyloxia at the end of the nineteenth century, and the industry was then devastated. Over the years the Hunter Valley and the Barossa Valley have grown at a much faster rate than the Victorian industry could. Now Victoria is again claiming its rightful place among the grape producing areas of the country as a major wine producer. Victoria has now become one of the great boutique wine producers, particularly of varietal wines. For many years the shiraz grape was one of the great premium grapes, producing great red wines. With the advent of the cabernet, merlot, malbec and pinot, among others, shiraz died away as a very popular wine, but it is pleasing to. note that the major winners of the wine show last Saturday were shiraz grapes. Any member who has an interest in red wine should now look very closely at Victorian shiraz. The wines are back at their peak again and the small Victorian producers specialising in shiraz are now producing wines of great complexity, with a great flavour of grape and great cellaring potential. In my electorate, particularly in the Heathcote area, la- many small vineyards are producing great varietal grapes, particularly in the shiraz and chardonnay areas. I do not want to get into a debate about which electorate or State has the best wine because, like the honourable member for Wakefield, I say that Australia, generally, produces some of the great wines in the world. It is interesting to note within the total industry the varietal characteristics that each area can produce. The varietal distinctions-different areas producing from different soils and different climatic conditionshave produced the great variety of wines for which the country is so famous. It is a great thrill for me to note that Australian wines are now winning awards throughout the world. It is interesting to note also that overseas producers, particularly the French, are now coming into Australia and investing heavily in our wine industry because they realise that we are leading the world in many fermentation techniques. Australia has developed some interesting fermentation techniques, particuprolarly the cold fermentation process, which other countries are now trying to emulate. We have a most exciting and technologically advanced industry, largely because our small producers are prepared to put their money where their mouths are and experiment with a whole variety of production techniques and grape varieties. It would be remiss of me if I did not give credit to the producers in my electorate, including Peter Touley and his wife at the MCIvor Creek Winery in Heathcote. They produce primarily shiraz, with some white wine production. In the area there is an association of wine producers, headed by Ron and Elva Laughton, who run the Jasper Hill Winery, and I recommend their wines. These wines are not often found in shops. The variety of wines available from each district is not readily available in shops. This is of a tragedy, because most of the larger brand producers, which sell in large volumes, manage to keep the wines of most of our smaller producers off the major bottle shop shelves. Yet the smaller producers' wines sell well, mostly from their own vineyards. The Victorian wine producing districts are increasingly moving into cold climate wines. It may surprise people to know that, even on the lower slopes of Mount Buller, which is a well-renowned ski area, the Delatite vineyard is producing some of the great pinot noirs produced in this country and its rhine riesling is a wine that must be experienced to appreciate both the beauty of the wine and the quality of the production. On the Strathbogie Ranges, which is quite miserable during winter and is a very cold area-(Quorum formed) Before I was interrupted I was going through the major vineyards in my electorate and extolling the virtues not only of my own electorate wines but of Australian wines generally. I was referring to the cold climate wine production in the Strathbogie Ranges. If honourable members want to taste cold climate wine, particularly the chardonnay variety, I can certainly recommend the Tisdale Mount Helen, which is grown in my electorate in very cold climate conditions. It is pleasing to note that there is now a major increase in production occurring in the Strathbogie Ranges. I have mentioned those various areas just to give an indication of the depth of variety and the innovation occurring amongst wine producers. At the show last Saturday night a large audience at the major function of the evening sat back and enjoyed some excellent Victorian wines and some very good Tasmanian sea trout. Australia is becoming a producer of quality foods and quality wine. I think this is what this legislation is all about. However, there are great problems. This is not to suggest that Australia is suddenly going to increase its export production easily. There are major tariff barriers in many places in the world which discriminate against the fine wines we are producing. An example very close to home is Thailand, where there is a 60 per cent tariff barrier against Australian wines. I have stressed on my visits to Thailand as Chairman of the Australian-Thai a bit Parliamentary Friendship Group that a country such as Thailand, which relies so heavily on tourism, should be removing the tariff barriers to allow greater access of Australian wines to their market. We are together in the Cairns trading group. We are both suffering as nations from distorted trading practices. It is appropriate that Thailand look very closely at removing that barrier to Australian wines. When I have travelled to Thailand I have found the price of wine prohibitive. A bottle of good Australian wine is frankly beyond the reach of most tourists. European wines are cheaper and more readily available. I would urge Thai Airways, who fly into this country, to get rid of their French wines and buy good Australian wines. We sell cheaper and better quality wines than most other places in the world. Very close to our own front door are areas of discrimination against this country's wine production and wine producers. The discrimination we face really makes us wonder. Yet one can travel to Europe, and even in England at Harrods, and buy Australian winesat a price that I could not afford, I might add. They are grossly overpriced, in my view, but nevertheless they are in the British market and in most European markets. One must give credit to the Wynyard Group in the Hunter, who have led the export market, for the way. they have broken down many export barriers and are now making Australian wines popular throughout the world. I understand now that the Californian market is opening up to Australian wines and I look forward to an increased presence of Australian producers there. I see that Penfolds has purchased a producer in California, where it will introduce into wine production Australian techniques and will be using that as a major base for the introduction of Australian wines, through its control of that wine production area, into California. That all augurs well for the future. It is an indication of quality win-s we have. I think the proposal to introduce some appellation controls-not full appellation, I might add-is to be encouraged. In the past there have been some unfortunate incidents where Australian producers have breached wine standards. The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation has investigated three instances lately of breaches of Australian wine standards. For example, in November 1988 sorbitol, a sugar naturally present in some fruits but not permitted in winemaking, was found in Tyrrells' wines. Tyrrells' export licence was suspended on 3 November 1988 and was not reinstated until 8 December 1988. The Health Department of New South Wales prosecuted Tyrrells and it was fined $120. In November 1988 there were indicators of apple juice present in Miranda wines. These are two examples of how an enormous market potential for Australia could be damaged by quite careless marketing techniques to change poorer quality wines to better tasting wines. I agree totally with the honourable member for Wakefield that if Australia is going to become a major exporter and increase its exports it is essential that we maintain integrity, that there be truth in labelling and that the wine be described by type and method of production and by area. As we go down the track I think we will see greater integrity in our wines and in our labelling processes. As I have indicated, the overall future is bright. The Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill is to vary the rate of levy-not so that the levy rate per se changes but rather so that the method of collection based upon tonnage pressed will change. The honourable member for Wakefield mentioned that the large producers have paid the same amount as smaller producers. As I have said, this is a progressive levy. It spreads the burden of the levy between the rate of production of grapes, which will spread the burden of the levy more fairly between small and large producers. The Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill has the wide support of the industry, as does all the legislation before the House now. We have an exciting industry in this country. I am a great lover of Australian wines and I occasionally taste foreign wines. I be the lieve that we are fortunate in the price we pay for our wines. The amount of wine sold in this country has reduced but it is interesting to note that the reduction has been in chateau cardboard, the major bulk wines that go into the container in the cardboard pack, and there has been an increase in the sale of bottled wine. That indicates that there is an increasing sophistication in the Australian wine market. It is no longer the case, as when I was a young man, that wine isrefe!red to as a 'sixpenny dark'. No longer are wme cellars the places they used to be in my youth where deros, as they were called, and other less savoury characters would sneak in, come out with a brown paper bag with a bottle of some unknown alcohol in it, and sidle off down the street drinking out of the bag. Those days have gone. Today Australia has a sophisticated wine market, a sophisticated consumer market and a sophisticated Australia-wide group of producers which deserve the total support of this House and this Parliament. I commend the Bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr EWEN CAMERON
Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Indi) (12.10)Very few honourable members in this place would not have some commercial wine production in their electorates. Of course, all of them are proud of their wine producers and the wine produced by them. I agree with the honourable member for MCEwen (Mr Cleeland), who said that this must be looked upon as a national industry, and our pride spreads right across the nation. I was very impressed by the comments made by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I know that some very fine wine is produced in his electorate and that the honourable member is very knowledgeable about the industry. I have had the pleasure of travelling to many States with the honourable member for Wakefield and other members of the Opposition, and talking to people involved in the Australian wine industry and discussing their problems. The three Bills before us today are the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill 1989 the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1989: and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1989, all of which are important pieces of legislation which will affect the Australian wine industry. I would like to confine my few remarks to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. It provides the legislative basis for the implementation by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation of a wine label integrity program. It is not an appellation scheme; it is an identification scheme to identify the product within the bottle or under the label. As the honourable member for MCEwen pointed out, this is a particularly important step forward in the industry because some other matters have intruded into those stated on the label and there have been some unfortunate experiences within the wine industry. The legislation requires that all wine facturers engaged in the process of wine production for commercial purposes keep a record of the vintage, variety, region of origin, source of supply and quantity of grape product received for use in making the wine. This will enable the Corporation to monitor claims made on the label by the manufacturers as to vintage, variety, region of origin and so on. Winemakers making these claims on labelswill also have to keep records relating to production, sales and disposal of the wine so that the Corporation may check the authenticity of claims made on wine labels. This program is a significant step forward in the remarkable progress made by the Australian wine industry in the production of quality wines. The honourable member for MCEwen referred to sixpenny dark, which was a port-styled fortified wine used by some people after the war. It was not drunk at the table or by the refined drinker. I must admit that I remember it as twopenny dark. That gives an indication of the inflation in those times. The days are long past when that was a favoured drink by some people. We now have world class table wines and world class fortified wines, and the industry has made enormous strides since those days. The controlled identification program will assist in creating even further confidence' in the consumer. The confidence that has been building up over the years will be taken further by this program. The program was overwhelmingly approved by the wine industry when it was put to the vote at the second annual general meeting of the Australian wine industry in Adelaide on 8 February this year. It was not a unanimous vote, but by far the largest number of producers welcomed the scheme. I am sure that those who did not vote for it will eventually see the merit of the scheme. At the meeting, the Corporation was asked to have the label integrity program in place for the start of the 1990 vintage. The confidence generated in the consumer market will enhance our export markets, which have enormous potentiaL They are very tough and competitive markets, but Australian producers of quality wine have made a real impact, a real dent, in those markets. We export to such countries as the United States of America, Canada, Japan, manu- the United Kingdom, Denmark, the Netherlands, the Federal Republic of Germany, Sweden, Norway, Finland and New Zealand, and to countries in South East Asia, and there is potential to export to many other countries. These markets will only be retained and expanded by maintaining our reputation for producing and delivering top quality wines. Another area in which the Government could assist the industry greatly in the production of top quality wines is taxation. I refer in particular to section 31A of the Act, which requires the winemaker to value and pay tax on wine at the time of manufacture. This, of course, creates liquidity problems and the manufacturer is often under financial pressure to sell his product well before it has had enough maturation time to become' a top quality wine. It would be of enormous value to the industry in its endeavours to further develop and expand export markets if the manufacturer could pay the tax at the time of sale rather than at the time of manufacture. The Government should take a hard look at these proposals. All three Bills have great merit. We as an Opposition support them, and I commend them to the House.  me pleasure to have the opportunity to enter this debate. The Bills have had great support from both sides of the House. They deal with a very important Australian industry, and it is only when one evaluates its impact upon Australia's image that one understands how great the wine industry is. For that reason I am grateful for the opportunity to speak on the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. This debate has given honourable members the opportunity to identify with their own areas and I, too, intend to become regional in my remarks. The legislation is of special significance to South Australia because that State is promoted as the Wine State. A grand prix starts in Adelaide at the end of this week and among its attractions are the wine growing areas in the regional and peripheral areas of Adelaide. From the time when wine was used for medicinal purposes, the humble grape has had a huge impact on society. This is demonstrated in the religious sacraments in the Christian As we take communion we hear the words 'And after He gave thanks He took the cup and said, "Drink ye all of this".' Wine has had a huge impact down through the ages and more particularly at present. In the colonial days of settlement, the names of Gramp, Seppelt, Penfold, Lehmann and Hardy were synonymous with wine development in Australia, and particularly South Australia. They have been joined by the other great names of Wolf Blass, the Hill--mith Yalumba family, Grant Burge, Brian Croser and many other emerging and great winemakers and oenologists. Certainly Roseworthy College in South Australia has had a good deal to do with the wine industry in Australia. Several other regional winemakers have been plying their craft in the regional areas from Coonawarra to the Riverland, the Southern Vales, the Adelaide Hills, Barossa Valley and Clare Valley and other pockets of wine production. We have heard other Government and Opposition colleagues speak of the Hunter area of New South Wales and the Victorian wine-growing areas. We should also mention the Leeuwin and Margaret River estates in Western Australia. The wine industry is huge. To protect this multimillion dollar industry, it is tant that its credibility be maintained and that is why it is important that the consumer be aware of the contents of a bottle. The main purpose of this Bill is to provide the basis for a wine label integrity program. Probably the most famous name in red wine is Penfold's Grange Hermitage. The father of Grange, the great winemaker, Max Schubert, AM, had to battle with his peers when he laid down the first bottle of his world famous red in the early 1950s. He was up against an industry that said that the wine would not survive, that it was an uncharacteristic red that had no quality and that it had to mature in the bottle. I am certainly grateful to members from both sides of the House who referred to Section 31A of the taxation Act, which I will close on eventually. But, if Max Schubert had been prevented from persisting with his skill and craft in developing that Magill grape into Penfold's Grange Hermitage, which is id-ntified by its label as being of excellent quality and characteristic of the grape, he would have faith. been prevented from producing one of the truly great red wines that Australia has seen. Label identification shows the integrity of the winemaker. It shows to the consumer the integrity of the grape. When one sees a bottle with the name chardonnay, pinot noir or fume blanc, one is aware of the contents. When one sees the names cabernet savignon or shiraz for red wines, one knows whether the wine is full-bodied or late on the palate. Wine is not elitist. Anyone can drink it and anyone does. It is said that someone's loss is someone else's gain. The biggest impact on Australia's wine industry came from the most horrific disaster known as Chernobyl. It had a huge impact on our wine industry. Australia was able to benefit from that and export vast quantities of grapes as either juice or wine. Here again, it comes down to the integrity of labelling. Consumers knew that our wine really was Chernobyl-free. It gave them confidence that what was in the bottle they were buying was what was on the label. Glass is a marvellous product that we are able to look through to see whether the wine is red or white but it does not help us to know whether it is a quality product. My colleague the honourable member for impor- MCEwen (Mr Cleeland) joked about the chateau cardboard. The trend has gone away from the chateau floodwaters and the chateau rotgut, because of people's satirical attitude, and towards the great varieties. People are choosing to purchase wine of quality rather than just quantity. I keep coming back to consumer faith and integrity in the product. When we analyse who benefits from and who impacts on the grape industry, there are the growers and the producers. My colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) spoke about fresh grapes, dried grapes and grape juice. He mentioned the pruners, the pickers, the cellar hands, the winemakers, the glass and packaging industry, the labelling, the corkage, the marketing and the retailing. Once the product is in the bottle, to whom do we sell it and what is done with it? That comes down to the consumers. Consumers are protected in everything they purchaseand rightly so-whether it is soft goods, cars or clothes. They should also be protected when buying wine. In' a pleasant, convivial atmosphere, wine can enhance a social occasion such as lunch or dinner. As I have said, it is not an elitist beverage. Anyone can drink it, although it is preferable that consumers are over the age of 18. That is the beauty of wine and the impact that it has. The honourable member for MCEwen touched on the quality and price of wine. One can buy a bottle of wine, whether red or white, for $9.99 and know from the label that it will be of reasonable quality. We also have cheap bottles of fizz that have to compete with the snobby, elitist, prestigious French market, with the champagne area of Europe. There is really not a great deal of difference between Great Western, Yellowglen and SeppeJts champagnes when stacked up against the Bollinger and Veuve Clicquot. The honourable member for MCEwen referred to Thailand. It is disappointing that there is a huge tariff barrier in Thailand of 60 per cent. I had the opportunity recently to travel to Japan. The Japanese love anything French in the way of wine. They love anything that has a chateau label and, after that, anything Californian. Australia. has a lot of work to do. I have done some research with Wolf Blass, a very entrepreneurial and charismatic wine producer in Australia. He says it is not enough for entrepreneurs to go overseas with a pallet of wine and a return air ticket and hope to crack the export market. Consumers in those markets know what they want. We will have to work on those markets. I congratulate Austrade for subsidising the effort put into the export promotion program with a grant of more than $100,000. The export potential must be there. We must seek to increase the one per cent share that Australia has of world wine exports and crack the market waiting there. Total wine exports have increased from $97m to $1l3m. That is an increase of 15 per cent or of 3 per cent in volume. Obviously, the production of grapes is increasing. The industry is in a state of flux at the moment because high prices have been paid for grapes. Wine producers have gone to New Zealand to buy very expensive pinot grapes to suit a vintage. As more wine comes on to the market, if consumer demand does not increase, we will have a glut of wine. We see from the daily newspapers that wine entrepreneurs are selling quality wine under $10 or $15, which makes it a very cheap beverage. We must work at removing the tariff barrier in Thailand and improving our export market to Japan. There is a good side and a bad side to everything. I am most concerned that the wine industry be aware of the anti-alcohol lobby group. Alcohol in moderation is tolerable. As more evidence is brought forward of the horrific crashes and deaths that occur on the· road, they are linked back, rightly or wrongly, to alcohol, under-age drinking or high speed in trucks, cars or buses. The industry will certainly come under scrutiny. It will have to do a lot of marketing to convince the community that alcohol in moderation is morally acceptable. While the industry appears rosy in some areas, it must be aware of the pressures from outside that will be placed upon it. We have seen the anti-tobacco lobby have success in winding down tobacco advertising. Likewise, I feel that there could be an anti-alcohol or wowser attitude to the wine industry. I want to include a few references to matters that have been touched on by other members, although I will not prolong this speech too much. The production of grapes for winemaking reached 554,000 tonnes in 1989. That represents a huge industry, ranking with some of our great primary production industries. It is a credit to that very well researched and organised industry. Unfortunately, as I have said, domestic sales declined by 6.9 per cent. I guess that increased costs have led to higher prices. The demand for lower priced, soft-pack wine has decreased, as the honourable member for MCEwen said, in that carton and cask industry, but the demand for quality bottled wine has inis creased. I have a particular bias towards some quality wines from my electorate that are obtainable across the length and breadth of South Australia. They really are a credit to Australia. Whichever regional area is sen, the winemakers are recognised. Bollinger has come back into Australia to share some if its skills, or perhaps to pirate the skills Brian Croser of Petaluma; Wolf Blass on the great Remy winehouse of France. we have this cross-pollination of ideas and skills. The wine industry deserves the supviveur. port that is provided in this legislation, which has received Government and Opposition support. Finally, I would like to support section 31A of the taxation Act, which seems to penalise stock at valuation-wine held for maturation. We encourage the winemakers of Australia to lay down their stocks and continue their degree of excellence. At wine shows around the world the consistent comwines ment is, 'These wines are sensational but why are they so young?'. Honourable meming. bers could go to any bottle shop, probably even in Parliament House, and buy a 1986 or 1987 bottle of red wine. That is a baby; it is a very young red to be drinking, but that wine were cellared and matured it be even greater. This part of the industry needs support and it should not be open to the rorts that may have taken place under section 31A. Winemakers must have the opportunity to continue this degree of excellence, to duce these great Australian wines and to keep us at the forefront of the industry. They deserve a lot of help to ensure that crack that great export market to help our chronic current account deficit and to mainof tain the great skills that have been developed in the winemaking industry throughout Auspation tralia.

text: A slow moving character like the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) can follow my lips as well. I repeat the point that I was making. It could be even better than that for Mr Elliott because he gets the bonus shares tax free. The significance of this has not gone unnoticed by commentators. One writing in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 July said: Mr Elliott knows of the coalition's commitment to abolish the capital tax gains tax on assets held for longer than five years. A change of government will certainly help increase the after-tax profits of the bid. Other commentators have noted that Harlin has ended up with an interest bill which far exceeds any dividends it is likely to receive on the Elders shares, concluding that Harlin must make some sales at some point. The absence of a capital gains tax obviously diminishes the risk in the Harlin bid. Elders can sell assets freed from capital gains tax and push those untaxed gains up to Harlin. It would all keep Humpty Dumpty glued together much better. And it was while Mr Elliott, on his own admission, was involved in the takeover of Elders IXL that he was also involved in the formulation of the Opposition's tax policy. Harlin's offer was announced on 5 July 1989. The part C bid commenced on 28 August 1989 and concluded on 25 September 1989. It is also instructive to know that the action of the Elders directors to bring down an early profit report on 21 September 1989, indicating a 5 per cent fall in the profits of Elders, had by common consent of financial market commentators contributed to the unexpectedly high take-up of the Elders offer. Many market commentators believe the bad profit report was brought on early to help the take-up of the $3 offer, which of course it did. The bottom line in Mr Elliott's involvement is this: It is he who has chosen to join the political debate; it is he who is the Federal President of the Liberal Party. He is not simply a manager and entrepreneur making the system work for him; he has decided to participate in the fortunes of a major political party, with all that that implies for policy, while he is juggling a massive corporate play in which he is personally involved. It is he who has described the Opposition's so called Economic Action Plan as taking from the bludgers and giving to the workers. It is he who is on the public record admitting that he was consulted in the formulation of the Opposition's tax policy and had a role in determining what went into the policy and what went out of the policy. We are saying that it suited Mr Elliott for the policy not to change-not for it to be backdated but for the policy not to change. The attitude of Opposition members is that this is all coincidence. It is coincidence that the President of their political party stands to gain quite literally hundreds of millions of dollars from the implementation of their\ policy. It is coincidence that this same man publicly boasts of his financial support of the Liberal Party and his involvement in formulating and reaffirming the Liberal Party's tax policy. It is significant that all we have received, in response to my remarks yesterday, is a very narrowly defined denial by the shadow Treasurer in his press statement about discussions of the Harlin bid and no denial at all about capital gains taxation generally, nor any denial from the Leader of the Opposition.

Mr Reith-Who declared war?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AIRLINE PILOTS DISPUTE
text: Order! The honourable member for Flinders!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: AIRLINE PILOTS DISPUTE
text: So there we had the announcement by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots of the prolonged industrial battle which it was going to undertake. That was the industrial dispute which it initiated. The Industrial Relations Commission has ended that industrial dispute. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots has no members employed. The pilots who are employed by the airlines are in no situation of industrial dispute. The airlines are the employers and pilots are employed by the airlines. There is no industrial dispute between them. This is an attempt by the discredited Federation of Air Pilots which will not accept the reality, as the Sydney Morning Herald says. It ignores reality. The reality is that the pilots have lost that industrial dispute. What we have is the aftermath of that industrial dispute. This Government stands ready, as we have said in consultations with the tourism industry. As this situation unfolds now we have received representations from the tourism industry. It has asked for no compensation. It has made it quite clear that it wants no compensation, but it wants us to cooperate with it in undertaking a campaign, which we will do, to restore the tourism industry to the position which was established under this Government. I remind this House that if there was one area of activity in this country that was almost criminally neglected by the mob opposite when they were in government it was tourism. When we came to office we had fewer than one million visitors from overseas-900,000. Under the policies of this Government that number has now reached about 2.2 million. We have revolutionised the tourism industry in this country, an industry which those opposite criminally neglected.

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Title: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SYSTEM
text: Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to recent reports of how Australia's industrial relations system could be transformed to one based on enterprise bargaining? What are the Government's intentions in this matter?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SYSTEM
text: Yesterday I detailed the Government's policy in relation to the change within the wages system, to industrial organisation within the wages system generally, to award restructuring and to enterprise agreements in industry unions to make the industrial relations system and the wages system more flexible and, therefore, more useful in terms of its role in economic growth. That followed the more general point that the Government has had to secure a change in aggregate wage outcomes from the very high levels of wage costs bequeathed to us by our predecessors. In the coalition document, the so-called Economic Action Plan, we have the key line that 'by reducing inflation and shifting the weight off monetary policy' the coalition is going to have a system of enterprise wage bargaining which will see, it says, 'a great leap downwards in wages'. It is going to enterprise bargain-like the Prime Minister was just s-ying in relation to Ansett and Australian Airlines-and wages are simply going to fall. Then inflation falls and, because inflation is the floor under interest rates, interest rates fall. It is all quite easy. All one does is go to enterprise bargaining and wages fall, inflation falls and interest rates fall. As my colleague - aid, today we have some very interesting words from Senator Chaney.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SYSTEM
text: Senator Chaney has come out of the shadows. He has been over therethat awfully decent, terribly honest, exceptionally earnest, mild-mannered senator from Western Australia, that all round goodygoody, Senator Chaney-sitting in silence ... But now that the honourable member for Bennelong has returned to the front bench and claimed industrial relations along with commerce and industry policy, he has jumped into print today, in the Australian, just to let us know that he is still around. He has some very interesting things to say. He says: The non-centralised system - . . that is, the Opposition's non-centralised systemwill look after itself provided the agreements are genuinely voluntary . . . So, provided they are genuinely voluntary, they will be okay. He goes on: . . . the industries are generally forced to be competitive, and that's really it. The fact that we have a British craft union structure, a trans-industry award structure, where a metal worker can be found under an award in the building industry, the car industry, the shipbuilding industry, one of a dozen industries, does not rate a mention'provided the agreements are genuinely voluntary'. Then he says: A Coalition government would encourage the commission to make these determinations largely on a 'capacity-to-pay' basis, . . . But on what basis would the capacity to pay be enforced? On what basis, if there has been an increase for a certain classification of worker in a certain industry, is a capacity to pay going to be established by the arbitration commission in the face of industrial activity? There is a total unwillingness to understand the realities of the workplace. I cannot get around it. Senator Chaney goes on to say that this industry-by-industry policy might mean some workers getting nothing. They will cop that, of course, because their industry cannot pay! The ones next door, with the same job classification, will get a bonanza but these people will cop it. It is the greatest lot of twaddle one could ever imagine. Senator Chaney then goes on to say that he: . would want to reach some consensus both employers and unions on the economic outlook . . . So, as he is giving one group nothing and another group everything, he is going to try to get a consensus about the way the whole thing should run. He says that while he is doing this 'there's a real risk' that the economy 'would be in hideous shape and we would face massive unemployment growth' So we will have high unemployment while he gets this consensus together about wages, while he has capacity to pay agreements and 'genuinely voluntary' agreements in relation to enterprise bargaining. This is the coalition's industrial relations policy. It is the greatest lot of rubbish ever. At the end of it, the writer herself says: It does not seem totally convincing. Dead right, Laura; it is not. Mr Speaker, this is the central tenet of the Opposition's policy. As I have been saying here for a week, when one looks past the bribes of tax expenditures, the give-aways, what sits under the lot? How would the Opposition run Australia? How would it deal with wages and costs and inflation? The answer is not by some process of evolution and change towards industry unions or enterprise agreements or a change in restructuring of awards. There would be none of that evolutionary change. The Opposition would pretend that the craft structure does not exist, turn its back on it and say, 'Go for your life. Bargain to your heart's content'. As the wage numbers fly up and the inflation rate flies up, it will respond with the same policy it has always responded witha draconian monetary policy which would tear the heart out of the economy: economic activity, imports and employment. Unemployment will rise. According to the Opposition, that will be good;· it will put a downward pressure on wage outcomes. Temporarily, the current account deficit will improve because imports will stop. So, too, will investment. Factories will start shutting their doors again. It will be exactly the same policy we had when the tragic trio were around in 1980, when the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong and Senator Stone were running economic policy in 1980. But here it is from the industrial relawith tions spokesman, who today has really put down some thoughtful lines about how the coalition would run this system. It is the nonsense I said it was yesterday and the day before. Not one person in the Opposition is prepared to stand up and defend it. The Leader of the Opposition has not had a press conference in Parliament 'House since he released the document 2t weeks ago. He will not subject himself to the kind of scrutiny that is required in seeking high public office as Prime Minister to run the national economy. He will not subject himself to scrutiny. He wants to satisfy the media by twominute interviews on kerbside with television journalists. He will not subject himself to the kind of detailed scrutiny of the Canberra Press Gallery on the key points of economic policy. All we have seen today is yet another example of the muddled thinking, emptiness and shallowness of the Opposition in these 'slim pickings', as they are called in the article, from Senator Chaney. This placed them, in this respect, on an equal footing with the High Court. The purpose behind this move was to place the courts and the Tribunal in a position where their funding allocation would be controlled by themselves and they will now be able to negotiate direct with the Government concerning the appropriate level of future funding. As an additional step towards increased administrative independence, a number of the departmental secretary's powers were delegated to the chief administrative officer of each court and of the Tribunal. This Bill now provides a statutory basis to fully implement the self-management of the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The effect of this Bill is to transfer from the Attorney-General's Department to the courts and the Tribunal responsibility for the supervision of their own financial management and practices and for the courts and the Tribunal to take control over the management of their other administrative affairs. Self-management will mean that the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be free to make their own decisions in human and financial resource management. This will maximise the flexibility of the courts and the Tribunal to cope with changing pressures and priorities throughout each year. the This move is welcomed by the chief justices of the Federal and Family courts and the President of the Tribunal. It is also consistent with initiatives they have taken, and no doubt will be taking, in relation to their case management procedures and in the reduction of delays. The Bill will also mean that these bodies will be given an administrative independence similar to that enjoyed by the High Court. There are two differences of substance between the arrangements in this Bill and the position of the High Court. First, unlike the High Court, the Federal and Family courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are not given power to acquire interests in land. The accommodation needs of these bodies are, of course, significantly greater than those of the High Court. Because of the geographic diversity of their operations, the Federal and Family courts and the Tribunal require facilities across Australia and the acquisition of those facilities is enhanced if they can have the opportunity to work under the umbrella of government purchasing and building arrangements. This is also a more efficient arrangement, in particular, where accommodation might be shared by these bodies in purpose-built accommodation. The other difference is that, unlike the High Court which operates its own bank accounts, the Federal and Family courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will operate on the Commonwealth public account under arrangements with which they are familiar and which they have agreed should be retained. Use of the Commonwealth public account will not subject them to the control of the Attorney-General's Department as they will operate as separate departments. To facilitate the proposed increased administrative responsibilities of the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Bill creates a new executive management position in each body to carry out the new management functions under the overall direction and control of the chief judge of each court and the President of the Tribunal. Unlike the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Family Court has two separate mainstreams of personnelthose concerned with the delivery of court counselling services and those concerned with the legal aspects of the proceedings before the court. In recognition of this fact-and noting, of course, that the Family Court is the largest and most diverse court in Australia-the Bill creates a new statutory office of Chief Executive Officer in that court. In the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal the responsibilities of the registrars have been altered to incorporate the responsibilities in respect of the courts and Tribunal administration previously conferred on the Secretary of the Attorney General's Department. Both positions of Registrar will cease to be Public Service positions and both registrars and the Chief Executive Officer will hold appointments from the Governor General. In relation to the other officers and staff of the courts and the Tribunal, the new officeholders will be given the powers of departmental secretaries. The existing position of the Principal Registrar of the Family Court will remain as at present and that officer will continue to exercise the functions of the Principal Registrar and the supervision of the officers of the court carrying out legal functions. Many of the ptovisions of the Bill are standard provisions and consequential amendments which are necessary for the creation of these new statutory offices. The remaining provisions in parts 2, 4 and 5 of the Bill cover the new administrative duties and responsibilities which are to be taken on by the courts and the Tribunal. The amendment to subsection 78 (3) of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act is also a consequential amendment arising from the change in the position of the Registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from a Public Service position to a statutory officeholder. Currently, the Registrar of the Tribunal is also the Registrar of the Security Appeals Tribunal established by the ASIO Act. This is because the workload of the Security Appeals Tribunal is such that it does not justify full time registry appointments. The amendment will mean that the Registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would still be eligible to be the Registrar of the Security Appeals Tribunal. The other amendments made by this Bill relate to the setting of fees in the High Court. Currently these fees are set by the judges of the High Court in the High Court rules. After consultation with the High Court, it has been agreed to transfer this fee-setting power so that in future it can be dealt with by regulation. This brings the position in regard to the High Court fees into line with the position in regard to fees in other courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill amends the relevant sections of the Judiciary Act to give effect to this proposal. This Bill is a major reform by the Government in the area of judicial administration. However, in presenting this reform, I must say that the Government is conscious that it could not have reached this point had it not been for the support and commitment of the chief justices of the Federal and Family courts and the President of the Tribunal. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned. Mr Jull- Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER -
