Title: BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill represents the first stage of legislation to reform the operation of broadcasting regulation. It contains measures that address some immediate deficiencies in the Broadcasting Act 1942. The Bill gives the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal access to more appropriate remedies in cases where a commercial radio or television licensee does not meet the basic suitability requirements that are currently applicable to a licence. It also includes amendments to confirm that the Minister can initiate, and the Tribunal can hold, joint inquiries into the grant of a licence for a supplementary or independent commercial FM radio service in a regional area; allow aspirant public broadcasters to transmit sponsorship announcements when conducting test transmissions; and allow public licensees to broadcast community promotional material. Further reforms are to be developed quickly and will be contained in amendments to be introduced in the autumn and Budget sittings of Parliament next year. The reforms to be introduced early next year will focus on measures to improve substantially the operation of key areas of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's responsibilities, in particular, the ownership and control enforcement scheme. These reforms will be consistent with the wider review. The final package, to be presented in the second half of next year, will incorporate the conclusions of the wider review of broadcasting regulation. I will deal now with the ownership and control provisions of the Bill. At present, Tribunal would be faced with extremely limited options if, after conducting an inquiry that it was required to hold, it were to find that a commercial licensee was no longer 'fit and proper', or no longer had the financial, technical or management capacity to provide an adequate and comprehensive service. It presently may only impose licence conditions or suspend, revoke or not renew the licence. But if the licensee's unsuitability was due the conduct or character of a person in a position to control the licensee company or its operations, licence conditions may not be an effective remedy. This is because the conditions may not be capable of affecting the influence of the relevant person on the licensee company. The only other remedies available-suspension, revocation or refusal to renew the licence-would put the service off the air. Cessation of a service would penalise not only the licensee company, but also the viewing or listening public and other innocent shareholders and creditors. There is a need to give the Tribunal more flexible and less draconian remedies. This Bill achieves that objective. The Bill allows the Tribunal, where it finds that a commercial licensee is no longer suitable to hold the licence, to issue specific directions to relevant parties and/or to impose appropriate licence conditions. These provisions do not create new substantive powers for the Tribunal. In the case of licence conditions, the Bill simply confirms that the existing power of the Tribunal under section 85 of the Act can be used as an alternative to licence cancellation. Similarly, in the case of directions, the Bill only extends the current directions power under section 92M of the Act to enable it to be used in the event of a failure by a licensee to meet basic suitability requirements. In some circumstances, licence conditions or directions may still be insufficient to deal with the situation. In these cases, the amendments allow the Tribunal to order divestment of relevant interests. If a relevant interest is directed to be divested a strict sixmonth deadline will apply. This is because by then it would have been fully established by the Tribunal, if necessary through court and Administrative Appeals Tribunal avenues, that the licensee failed to meet the the suitability requirements and that divestment was the appropriate remedy. At this stage the Government proposes no change to arrangements for any divestment that may be required in other circumstances, such as following a breach of ownership limits. The Bill also provides powers for the Tribunal to impose licence conditions and to issue directions to apply pending divestment. These powers will mirror the existing provito sions that are available to the Tribunal pending its consideration of a share transaction. The purpose of this power is to enable the Tribunal to prevent actions that might adversely affect the service. The range of licensing remedies provided in this Bill enables the sanctions of licence suspension or revocation to be put in a clearer perspective. These remedies are best used as an ultimate deterrent against repeated or serious breaches of the Act. This Bill will remove concern that such draconian actions could be taken by the Tribunal because it had no other real alternative. At this point I would like to refer more generally to the powers that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has long held under section 85 to impose licence conditions at any time and, under section 92M, to issue directions pending an inquiry into an ownership transaction. In recent months some doubt had been cast on the possible validity of the section 92M power and a possible procedural requirement may have inhibited its use in practice. These doubts had led to calls for additional powers to be provided to the Tribunal. In the light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, the Government now considers that the current section 92M powers are valid. There are no undue obstacles to the use of these powers, - r to the imposition of licence conditions, in cases where such steps would be properly warranted by the circumstances. Accordingly, the Government is not proposing any amendments in this respect at this stage. This Bill also makes some minor adjustments and clarifications that reinforce existing policy and do not pre-empt the Government's ongoing review of broadcasting regulation, about which I will say more later in these remarks. The Bill places beyond doubt the power of the Tribunal to inquire concurrently into applications for grant of both commercial radio licences and supplementary licences in the same market. These amendments answer arguments that the Act may require those applications to be considered sequentially, an interpretation that could substantially delay the introduction of new, competitive radio services in non-metropolitan markets. The Bill also will permit public broadcasters to transmit community promotional material. Presently, public broadcasters may transmit community information which, under recent interpretations, may not be promotional in nature. The Government considers that this is too restrictive and that public broadcasters should be able to promote actively genuine community events of interest to their listeners. While the promotion of commercial sponsors will continue to be prohibited as a form of advertising, the Government is considering the implications of recent Tribunal findings and a Federal Court decision on these aspects and may propose further clarifying amendments if that seems necessary. The amendment has been cast in broad terms on the basis that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has power to make program standards in this area if the Tribunal considers that to be appropriate. The Bill will also allow public broadcasters undertaking test transmissions to broadcast sponsorship announcements as if they were licensed services. This will assist aspirant public groups to pay for the tests, and enable them to gauge the level of support likely to be available within the community. Any breaches of the sponsorship requirements during the test would be an offence, and may also be taken into account by the Tribunal when it comes to determining who should be licensed. The continued growth of public broadcasting as an integral element of the Australian broadcasting system is fully appreciated by the Government and these amendments will continue to assist that growth. The changes proposed today serve to introduce immediate improvements to the present system. The basic legislation needs further improvement. I turn now to the question of further, more fundamental, reform. The Broadcasting Act has rightly been described as a complex, unwieldy piece of legislation. The Government is committed to its ongoing reform. In November 1988, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure tabled a report making recommendations on changes to the role and functions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. This was followed by a supplementary report in May 1989. Both reports have proved to be valuable contributions in pointing out deficiencies in the present system and setting out issues for reform. In July of this year, I released a departmental discussion paper entitled Review of Broadcasting Regulation that focused mainly on the current regulatory system and suggested some options for change. Public comment was sought on that paper. Most of the submissions received so far in response to the departmental discussion paper have argued for extensive changes to the system of broadcasting regulation. Several interest groups have asked for more time to address the issues before making their full submistings sions, and I have agreed to this. The public debate has provided valuable further perspectives on difficult problems. There is widespread agreement on the need to introduce measures to increase the effithe ciency and effectiveness of the ownership and control scheme. But, even more imporrelated tantly, there has been general support, erly qualified by the need to protect the public interest, for the view that there would be merit in a more wide-ranging examination of broadcasting regulation. The submissions consistently argued for this. I have asked my Department to proceed with options for ongoing reform, building on the reforms already introduced by this Govling ernment. In 1987 this Government fundaup mentally reformed the television ownership and control limits in the Act. The following year we reformed the limitations on the ownregulation ership and control of commercial radio staaspects tions. We replaced the old two-station rule for television ownership with limitations based on audience reach. We replaced the old limits on radio station holdings with new limits which recognised growth and developsettled ment in the radio industry. We also introa duced cross media limits between radio, television and newspaper outlets in the same marketplace. Broadcasting ownership and control policies have thus been clearly stated and implemented by this Government. The tives, rules embodying these policies have been down in the Act. In this area efficiency renecessary. forms are now called for. At present the limitations on ownership and control are enforced by complex mechanisms, including an extensive system of notification and approval of a wide range of commercial transactions. Other areas of commercial activity do not have the same degree of oversight upon them-be it by the Trade Practices Commission, the National Companies and Securities Commission, or the Australian Stock Exchange. This is beefficient cause, historically, the community and the Parliament have considered broadcasting warrant a higher level of public scrutiny. However, there needs to be a mechanism to scrutinise and enforce ownership and control limits by means that impose less of a burden on licensees, investors and the Tribunal. I intend to bring forward in the autumn sitnext year a package of measures to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the ownership and control scheme. Ownership and control rules serve four separate main purposes. The first is to limit concentration of ownership, control and influence of the media. The second, which is to the first, is to encourage competiproption and diversity in programming and the range of views to be presented. The third is to restrict foreign ownership. The fourth is to support the present licensing requirements including the suitability of prescribed interest holders in individual licences. There may be merit in developing legislation that addresses these aspects separately, so that non-controlinvestors are not unnecessarily caught in regulation addressing the suitability of those who control licences and so that there is greater consistency with general business that affects foreign ownership or of ownership that affect competition. This 'efficiency package' may also streamline the Tribunal's public inquiry processes. However, in addition to taking immediate steps to introduce efficiency reforms in well areas of broadcasting policy there is need to examine the principles of broadcasting regulation from a wider perspective. This aspect of the review will be directed at ensuring that future legislation more clearly serves explicit governmental policy objecin particular, that the industry is sublaid ject only to the minimum regulation Clearly, full deregulation is not appropriate for this industry because it involves so many important public interest issues. For . that reason appropriate licensing arrangements and standards are still necessary, as are rules to limit cross media ownership, audience reach and multiple licence ownership. The regulation that is retained in the revised scheme will need to be capable of administration. There will need to be certainty for all affected parties, while to maintaining appropriate public access and providing for natural justice. Because of the high level of public interest in this area, I will now outline briefly its scope and the direction that the Government will be pursuing in its ongoing reform of broadcasting regulation. We will be addressing seven key areas. First, future broadcasting legislation must serve the explicit policy aim that there be no more regulation of industry than is necessary to support stated objectives. The Government has previously spelled out objectives that address diversity and quality of programming, Australian content, local programming needs, concentration and diversity in broadcasting media ownership and control. It is the responsibility of government to provide the environment in which broadcasting objectives can best be met. This requires further consideration of the proper balance between structural measures-including an appropriate level of competition, perhaps linked to some selfregulation-and external regulation. Secondly, there is the area of new services and service delivery methods. The current scheme of legislation in broadcasting, radiocommunications and telecommunications needs to be re-examined to recognise the interactions between broadcasting services and broadcasting-related services, such as video and audio entertainment and information services, or VAEIS, and narrowcast services; between broadcasting services and some emerging value added telecommunications services; between broadcasting services and the cinema, video-hire and other VCR-derived services; and between broadcasting and the Australian film, music and entertainment production industries. This is certainly not to say that any regulation should be applied uniformly-or at allto the various types of services; indeed quite the contrary. When I released my Department's discussion paper, I said that the Government is committed to ensuring that services are not subjected to unnecessary regulation. Where different technical or commercial arrangements deliver services that are essentially similar to the user, it is inappropriate to subject them to different regulatory regimes. At present there are quite different regulatory arrangements governing programs provided in the cinema, on videotape or through broadcasting. But as the differences in the means of access to programs become less significant, the regulatory differences need to be reduced or eliminated. New applications for communications technology are being developed, and the distinction between broadcasting services and these new applications is becoming increasingly unclear. We need regulation that facilitates and encourages these new services. This means that they should not be subject to ad hoc regulatory arrangements; nor should they be artificially forced into a traditional-and even outdated-broadcasting regulatory regime. At the same time we need to recognise the interlocking nature of the various pieces of communications legislation, and continue to ensure their consistency and integration, and their relevance to what is happening out there in the real world. But this does not necessarily mean an all-embracing single communications Act. Rather it means the progressive updating of the legislation to achieve the objectives. The third area comprises all those activities that are traditionally referred to as 'planning'. Communications planning processes need to be restructured to ensure accountability through a more transparent process. Present arrangements require the Minister and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to be heavily involved in judgments about when a service area needs or can support new commercial services. We need to develop arrangements that provide greater scope for broadcasters to take initiatives and carry them forward on their own responsibility to tap new markets and new market segments. We also need to examine whether community needs are better recognised and met by the integration of planning and licensing arrangements under the umbrella of an independent authority. The fourth area is. that part of the Act dealing with ownership and control. The continuing need for limitations on ownership and control in the broadcasting industrynotably in the areas of foreign ownership, audience reach, cross media limits-is generally accepted. Efficiency reforms are now called for in the regulatory mechanisms which presently supervise and enforce these limits and I intend to introduce such reforms in the autumn sittings next year. The wider review, however, may consider other aspects standards. of ownership and control not dealt with in the efficiency package. The licensing system is the fifth area. needs to be examined to achieve a more agencies efficient and rational approach to licence location, review, and renewal. A broadcastlatory ing licence is still a valuable and marketable asset. There is a case for greater use of pricing mechanisms in licenCe allocation. This is the basis of the Government's national metropolitan radio plan and has already used in the process of AM-FM conversion for commercial metropolitan radio stations in all the mainland State capital cities. is now scope to extend such arrangements further. At the same time, a licence carries with certain public responsibilities and there minimum suitability and service ments that need to be met. The present legislative formulation of these requirements warrants further examination. However, whatever the outcome of such examination, allocation methods will need to continue take account of these responsibilities and quirements; and regulatory powers are needed in this area. The present Bill addresses some of the immediate problems in this area of licensing. But there is a need for further efficiency amendments and scope for further and more fundamental reform. This will be addressed with a view to developing arrangements support the objectives of diversity, quality, and responsive commercial programming while eliminating undue regulatory intervention. Sixth, the regulation of programming standards needs to be examined to ensure that quality is maintained in the broadcasting system. It is the Government's responsibility to safeguard the public interest, but this be achieved by creating the right environment for industry to provide services of an acceptable standard. The question of whether standards need to be established statutory regulation or self-regulation needs to be looked at. However, this Government has no intention of abandoning its support for Australian content, quality children's programming and safeguards for community The seventh, and final, area involves the re-examination of the nature, responsibilities This and method of operation of the regulatory and the divisions of responsibilities albetween them and the Government. Regupolicy is a matter for the Government and the Parliament. However the administration of regulation, as well as the provision of advice on its substance, can be and is presently assigned to, different regulatory agen- . been cies. Arrangements for administering regulation need to be consistent with the policy objectives for that regulation. While There we need appropriate transparency and accountability in important regulatory decision-making, we also need to find ways to streamline procedures so that regulatory it processes provide opportunities for commuare nity involvement and do not unduly impede requirecommercial arrangements. While many of these issues have been addressed to some extent by recent review activity, we need to look at them again from a to wider, more fundamental perspective. Proreposals received during recent public consultations provide a valuable foundation for this exercise. In examining future options, there will be wide consultation, both within the Government and with all interested parties outside government. The Government wants to see the fullest public debate. This will include scope for further public comment directed to the Department of Transport and that Communications throughout the review process and the release of position papers on relevant issues as the review progresses. The Australian broadcasting industry has generally met audience and community needs well over many years. While we need· to maintain continuity with this past achievement, we also intend to ensure that arrangements are in place to foster new and emerging can market opportunities and to meet commuregulatory nity needs and aspirations. The Government does not underestimate the complexity of the task that we have set by ourselves. Those who may suggest that the fundamentals of broadcasting regulation are amenable to quick or simple reform fail to comprehend either the complexity and importance of the issues or the constraints of the existing legislation. Nonetheless we would hope to be in a position to introduce further legislation to improve regulatory efficiency during the autumn sittings, with the balance of our reform program being presented during the Budget sittings. The Bill is expected to have no significant· impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The principal purpose of the Bill is to amend the Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985 and associated regulations to allow different rates of levy to be determined for the various grain legumes covered by the grain legume research scheme. In recognition of the higher per unit value of crops recently added to the scheme, the maximum rate of levy prescribed in the Act is proposed to be increased from $2.60 to $5 per tonne. The Bill also provides for an increase in the levy rate for peanuts from $1.25 to $2 per tonne and changes of an administrative nature in respect of peanuts and mung beans. All changes have been recommended by the Grains Council of Australia, which is the growers' organisation defined in the Levy Act. The Grain Legumes Levy Act, in conjunction with the Rural Industries Research Act 1985, gives effect to a grain legumes research scheme, which is funded by a levy payable by growers on the production of certain grain legumes. The levy rate is presently $1.25 per tonne for all leviable grain legumes, which can be varied by regulation up to a maximum rate of $2.60 per tonne. Grower contributions to research by way of the levy, are 1989 matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the industry's gross value of production. Australian grain legume production has increased very markedly over the past decade and today makes a significant contribution to the Australian cropping industry. Moreover, the industry has developed into a major rural commodity export earner. NaOrtional production in 1988-89 is estimated at over 1.8 million tonnes valued in excess of $400m. Exports for the same year were in excess of 782,000 tonnes valued at $207m. Improved prices relative to cereals have been a significant factor in the strong growth in grain legume production. There is, however, increasing recognition among the farming community of the value of grain legumes as a rotational crop, both to provide nitrogen for subsequent cereal crops and to assist in the control of cereal diseases. Grain legumes are thus expected to continue to play an important part in farm management, as well as broadening the market base for rural producers. Reflecting the increased grower interest in grain legumes in recent years, the Government· has approved a number of additions to the grain legumes research scheme. Initially, only lupins and field peas were leviable under the Act. Faba beans, chick peas, mung beans, pigeon peas and peanuts have since been included. The value per unit of production of the crops added to the scheme, however, varies considerably from that of lupins and field peas. The objective of the proposed amendments to the Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985 contained in this Bill is to provide for a levy determination mechanism for grain legumes leviable under the Act to more closely reflect the price received by the grower for the particular crop grown. It will assist growers of all grain legumes covered by the scheme to reach the target level of 0.5 per cent of gross value of production which the Government considers to be the appropriate minimum level of industry contributions to research. Contributions to that level receive the benefit of full matching contributions by the Commonwealth. The amendment will provide for different rates of levy to be payable on individual leviable grain legumes or groups of leviable grain legumes by way of regulation. The maximum rate for any levy under the scheme will continue to be prescribed in the Act, but is to be increased to $5 per tonne as requested by the growers' organisation. The first grain legume proposed to attract a separate levy rate is peanuts, which for administrative efficiency is prescribed in the legislation in this instance. The rate of $2 per tonne has been the subject of a specific recommendation of the growers' organisation as required by the Levy Act. Also in regard to peanuts, a change to the legislation is necessary to ensure that the levy is applied on an 'in shell' basis, reflecting the fact that a proportion of production is sold in that form. In relation to the financial implications of the Bill, the higher levy rate for peanuts will generate an estimated additional $29,700 in industry contributions to the Grain Legumes Research Trust Fund in the first full levy income year. Provision has been made for the increased Commonwealth matching contribution to commence in the 1990-91 financial year, at the level appropriate to a commencement date for the Act of 1 January 1990. None of the remaining provisions of the Bill have direct financial implications. The Bill also provides for the addition to the scheme, by regulation, of the mung bean species Vigna mungo. The addition is necessary to ensure that all commercially grown species of mung bean are listed and thus leviable. The existing Grain Legume Research Levy Regulations will be made redundant by the legislative amendments proposed and are to be repealed. The Amendments provide express authority for further levy rates to be prescribed by regulation subject to the maximum rate prescribed in the Act. Subject to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill entering into force, .the grain legumes research scheme will continue to be administered by . the Grain Legumes Research Council. It is envisaged that the scheme will be administered in due course as part of the proposed Grains Research and Development Corporation, reflecting the close links between cereal and grain legume crop production. The commencement date of this legislation will be a date to be proclaimed. A commencement date of 1 January 1990 would accord with existing provisions of the Act and ensure that all peanuts harvested in the 1989-90 season attract the higher rate of levy. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Jull) adjourned. Title: COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of the Australian Heritage Commission Amendment Bill is to implement changes to the operations of the Australian Heritage Commission as agreed by the Government following a comprehensive public review of the Commonwealth Government's role in the conservation of the National Estate. Each of the amendments proposed in the Bill is concerned with one or more of the following matters: clarification and improvement of the Commission's operational procedures; the inclusion of powers for the Commission to administer the national estate grants program; the removal of a subsection unnecessarily discriminating against Aboriginal sites; tQe exemption of authorities of the self-governing Territories and Australian Airlines from the requirements of the Act, in accordance with government policy; and administrative changes to clarify certain operations of the Act and correct some minor technical defects. Before examining the provisions of the Bill in detail, let me first explain the history of, and the principles underlying, the Australian Heritage Commission Act and the reasons why the proposed amendments are considered essential. The Australian Heritage Commission Act was passed by the Commonwealth Parliament in 1975 following a major public reviews conducted during 1973 and 1974 by the Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate under the chairmanship of Mr Justice R. M. Hope. The principal recommendation of the Committee of Inquiry was that a commission be established to administer National Estate matters and that its enabling legislation contain provisions obliging all Commonwealth agencies to act so as to ensure maximum possible conservation of all items in the National Estate. The original Act was amended in 1976 following a review by the new Government of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. The amendment Act of 1976 reaffirmed the key elements of the original Act as recommended by the Hope Committee. The main amendments related to the removal of specific powers from the Commission to advise the Government on expenditure and grants of financial assistance-the current Bill aims to restore this power; a reduction in the number of commissioners from 19 to seven; a provision to limit the Commission's power to enter Aboriginal places in the Register of the National Estate-the Bill aims to repeal this provision; the removal of permanent head powers from the Chairman of the Commission; and a provision requiring the Commission to seek the approval of the Minister before appointing committees-the Bill aims to remove that limitation. Since 1976 there have been a number of other changes to the Act but these have concerned specific administrative issues such as Public Service reform; they have not affected the fundamental principles of the Act. The Commission thus remains comprised of a part time chairman and up to six part time commissioners with various skills and interests related to the natural, Aboriginal or historic environment. The Commission's main responsibilities can be summarised as: Preparing and maintaining a register of National Estate places; advising the Commonwealth· Minister responsible for the environment on all matters relating to the National Estate; advising other Commonwealth Ministers and government authorities on Commonwealth Government proposals which might affect the National Estate; and developing policies and programs for research, professional training and public information and education. In addition, the Act requires that before a Commonwealth Minister, Department or authority takes any action which might significantly affect the National Estate values of a registered place the Commission is informed of the proposal and given reasonable opportunity to consider it. The Act also requires that no action be taken by a Commonwealth Minister, Department or authority that adversely affects a place in the Register, unless there is 'no feasible and prudent alternative', and if there is no such alternative then all necessary measures must be taken to minimise the effects. These responsibilities - of the Commission, Commonwealth Ministers and agencies have remained unchanged since 1976. However, they were again subject to review in 1978 and 1979-this time by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, chaired by the Hon. John HodgeS, MP. In general, the Committee concluded that the Act and the operating procedures of the Commission were satisfactory and appropriate. All the recommendations of the Hodges Committee for amendments to the Australian Heritage Act will be implemented by this Bill. In June 1985, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Hon. Barry Cohen, MP, announced yet another review of the Australian Heritage Commission Act. The purpose was to assess whether, after 10 years, the mechanisms were still adequate and appropriate and to recommend changes where necessary. The Minister invited public submission from all interested parties including State and Territory governments, local government, conservation groups and development groups. Over 150 submissions were received and a two-day seminar held to discuss the review attracted over 100 participants. The report of the review, which also took into account the Hodges Committee report and representations made to the Government on the operations of the Act, was distributed to all interested parties in August 1986, with an invitation for comments before final recommendations were made for amendments to the Act. Honourable members can readily see that the amendments proposed in this Bill have not been lightly arrived at. Since its passage by the Parliament in 1975 the Australian Heritage Commission Act has been the subject of intense public scrutiny and almost constant review by government or the Parliament. This. process has identified a number of desirable changes to the Act to improve the Australian Heritage Commission's efficiency and effectiveness. However, it has also demonstrated beyond doubt the Commission's essential ongoing role in the Commonwealth Government's efforts to conserve and protect the National Estate. The Commission's achievements have been considerable: It has established a substantial database places of National Estate significance. includes over 9,000 places entered in the Register of the National Estate and the interim list of the Register of the National Estate. Using its database, the Commission provides advice on the National Estate to a wide range of Commonwealth Ministers, departments and authorities. In 1988-89 the Commission provided such advice under section 30 of its Act on 336 occasions. In addition, the Commission's expertise on National Estate matters is acknowledged by State and local government and private firms and individuals. The Commission's advice is often sought even though there is no statutory requirement. This occurred 83 times in 1988-89. Educational activities to foster understanding of the National Estate have also been at the forefront of the Commission's priorities. The publication of The Heritage of Australia-The Illustrated Register of the National Estate in 1981 followed by individual State editions for Tasmania, South Australia and the Northern Territory, and Western Australia, have been significant milestones. Film. co-productions such as the The Land of the Lightning Brothers and the highly acclaimed Nature of Australia: Portrait of an Island Continent have added substantially to Australians' awareness of and concern for the National Estate. As the Commonwealth Government's principal advisory body on matters related to the National Estate, the Australian Heri- . tage Commission has often faced a difficult task in carrying out its responsibilities. The Commission has been required to provide the Government with National Estate advice on some highly controversial is-ues-the destruction of the Belle Vue Hotel in Brisbane, the Franklin Dam and the wet tropics of Queensland, to name but a few. Nevertheless, its activities are not limited to such issues. Much of the Commission's most effective work is carried out in collaboration with government and the private sector, out of the public limelight. This often leads to real achievement in the conservation of the National Estate-without controversy, withof out confrontation and without any public This attention or fanfare. This has been recognised by the Government in considering the review of its role in the conservation of the National Estate. While some legitimate concerns have been raised about the Commission's operations, these can be readily addressed through the amendments proposed in this Bill. The fundamental need for the National Estate to be . conserved through the continued operation of the Commission is undeniable. Community and Government support for this proposition has grown even stronger since its initial articulation in the Hope report of 1974. This is not to say that there has not been some misunderstanding of the Commission's role. Indeed, I suspect that this misunderstanding, particularly regarding the effect of having a place listed on the Register of the National Estate, has been deliberately and mischievously fostered by some development interests opposed to Commonwealth Government actions to conserve the National Estate. Of course, this is the nub of the matter. People and organisations opposed to the Government's overall environmental policies often cannot or will not distinguish the basic concept of the Register of the National Estate from decisions made by government on issues involving the National Estate. In fact the Australian Heritage Commission simply identifies the National Estate and advises on National Estate values. It has no power of intervention or proscription. It is the Government which is responsible for deciding about 'feasible and prudent alternatives' to actions affecting National Estate values. It is also incorrect to claim that listing on the Register of the National Estate somehow locks up areas or forecloses options for economic and social development. There are many examples throughout Australia of listed areas being used for economically productive purposes which do not have an unacceptable impact on the heritage values of the area. Calls for greater ministerial control of the Commission or the inclusion of other than National Estate criteria-for example, economic significance-in the registration process are therefore particularly ill-founded. Parliament advisedly gave the Australian Heritage Commission an independent statutory role in registering places of National Estate significance and bringing them to the attention of Commonwealth Ministers and agencies. The judgments required in registration decisions are not and should not be political. They should be objective and backed by expert scientific assessment. Only through such a process can heritage values be considered alongside other values-land use, economic and so on-when government decisions are being taken. Turning now to the specifics of the Bill, clauses 1 and 2 deal with the short title and commencement date. Clause 3 relates to interpretation and raises a number of issues. The definition of 'authority of the Commonwealth' will be amended to remove the authorities or bodies established under the laws of the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island and Australian Airlines from the requirements of the Act. This is in accordance with the Government's policy of treating the self-governing Territories as States in most respects and with its decision to make Australian Airlines more commercially competitive. Terms used in the proposed new part of the Act dealing with the National Estate grants program (NEGP) are also defined. Definitions of the interim list and of the term 'owner' as used in describing those persons that the Commission must inform before publishing a notice of intention to register a place are also included. Clause 4 will insert into the Act specific criteria against which places under consideration for entry in the Register will be measured. This will clarify the definition of the National Estate already included in the Act and will reflect procedures which have been used by the Commission for some time. Clause 5 will reinstate the original wording of paragraph 7 (a) of the Act as originally passed and extend its provisions to allow the Commission to give advice on identification of the National Estate as well as its conservation, improvement and presentation. The reinstatement of subparagraphs concerning advice on expenditure and financial grants will be consistent with the Government's decision to transfer the administration of the National Estate grants program to the Commission. Clause 5 will also insert specific functions in the Act for the Commission to administer the NEGP. Clause 6 makes it clear that the Commission may enter into contracts. The Act has no specific provision for this at present. Subsection 22 (5) of the Act provides for the removal of a place from the register. Clause 7 of the Bill will provide for the removal of part of a place from the register. Clauses 8 to 12 reflect the need recognised in the review for the operational procedures of the Commission to be more 'transparent' to public scrutiny. Hopefully, these changes will help inform people of the Commission's role and avoid some of the misconceptions I noted earlier. The proposed amendments provide detailed procedures for the entry or removal of a place in the Register including the notifying of owners, the provision of location maps and statements of significance, the handling of objections, the appointment of independent assessors by the Minister, and clarification of the operation of the interim list. Although objections to proposed registrations may be submitted on any grounds, the Bill makes it clear that the Commission must give prime consideration to the National Estate significance of places. Clause 8 also provides for the repeal of subsection 23 (5) which currently restricts the Commission's ability to enter Aboriginal sites in the register. This subsection was introduced as an amendment in 1976 to avoid possible conflicts between decisions by the Commission on the registration of land and recommendations by land commissioners on Aboriginal land rights. The subsection is an unnecessary discrimination against Aboriginal sites and, on the experience to date, its removal will not result in the conflicts forecast in 1976. Clause 13 of the Bill will legitimise an existing practice whereby. the Commission is normally given an opportunity to comment on proposed actions by Commonwealth Ministers and agencies that might significantly affect a registered place. The proposed amendment will require the Commission to provide comments as soon as practicable. Clause 14 deals with the National Estate grants program and will transfer· its administration from the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act to the Australian Heritage Commission Act. No major changes are proposed to the nature or administration of the program except a provision for the Minister to make grants to approved bodies directly as well as at present through State and internal Territory governments. Section 39 of the Act includes a requirement that the Commission must obtain the approval of the Minister before entering into a contract involving the payment or receipt of an amount exceeding $50,000. Clause 15 of the Bill will increase the amount to $200,000, reflecting inflation and the growth of the Commission. Clause 16 will permit the Commission to appoint committees without restriction, returning to the original wording of the Act. Clause 17 will correct technical deficiencies in public notices published prior to 20 November 1979. These deficiencies were minor in nature and the Bill will validate the notices which included them. This Bill re-affirms the basic principles underlying the Australian Heritage Commission Act while at the same time introducing a series of improvements to the operational procedures of the Commission. These improvements will clarify the Commission's role, make it more open and more accountable, yet retain its independence as the Commonwealth Government's principal advisory body on the National Estate. Australia is fortunate in having a unique heritage which in large part has not been degraded or destroyed like some other countries. However, this means that we have an even greater responsibility to protect it for future generations. This Bill should be seen as a measure of the Common-. wealth Government's determination to do so. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr MCGauran) adjourned. HOUSING ASSISTANCE BILL 1989 Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Title: COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The Housing Assistance Bill 1989 authorises the Commonwealth to enter into a new 10year housing agreement with the States, the Northern Territory and for the first time, j the Australian Capital Territory, and appropriate moneys for financial assistance to the States and these Territories for housing purposes in 1989-90 and for the years 1990-91 to 1992-93. The Hawke Labor Government was elected in March 1983 with a firm commitment to renegotiate Federal housing arrangements with the States. The key objective of this Government's housing policy platform was to ensure that all Australians had access to adequate and appropriate accommodation 1975 at a price they could afford. The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA) is the Commonwealth Government's major housing program. It aims to relieve housing-related poverty and to deliver housing assistance equitably to people in different housing tenures. Financial assistance has been provided to the States under a series of such agreements since 1945. In 1984 we introduced legislation for the Housing Assistance Act 1984 and a new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to take effect from 1 July 1984. That agreement reflected the consensus view of Commonwealth and State housing Ministers of how best to deliver an effective and equitable program of public housing assistance and demonstrated our commitment to a long term public housing strategy. We backed up these changes with massive funding levels. In the five years ended 1988-89, we provided almost $3.4 billion under the CSHA, more than double the $1.6 billion provided in the last five years of the previous Government. Our initiatives have allowed us to boost the stock of public housing dwellings considerably, from 245,000 at 30 June 1983 to 316,000 at 30 June 1988, an increase of almost 30 per cent. While public housing accommodates about 5 per cent of all Australian households, it is targeted to those most in need in our society. At 30 June 1987 almost 70 per cent of public housing tenants were on pensions or benefits representing 26 per cent of the total number of pensioners and beneficiaries who rent. Almost one in four families with children who rent live in public rental dwellings. These figures show that our targeting of public housing assistanceand the level of funding provided have made a major impact on housing related poverty in this country. But pressure on public housing has continued to grow and there is an ongoing need to ensure that our programs remain well targeted and effective. Against this background, we undertook a major review of the existing policies and practices under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement with the aim of identifying improved strategies for the future. This review found that the viability of the CSHA was under threat and that unless action were taken by the Commonwealth, there would be a significant diminution of States' public housing effort in future years. This was because States had been using commercial borrowings to meet their matching requirements and the resulting debt servicing obligation, combined with a growing rent rebate bill, had been eroding their capacity to fund new public housing. The review concluded that significant changes should be made to the current arrangements for financing, targeting and administering public housing. The review recommended a number of specific changes to CSHA provisions for funding, including changes to matching and the use of funds. These recommendations were designed to put the provision of public housing on a more secure long term financial basis, and to ensure States make a greater financial contribution to the provision of public housing. Following consideration of these recommendations, we put forward a proposal to the States for a new CSHA at the May 1989 Premiers Conference. After detailed negotiations with States, a new agreement was developed which forms part of this Bill. The new agreement will represent the most significant reform of public housing since the CSHA was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1945. At the same time, the principles introduced by this Government in the 1984 agreement remain valid. These are to alleviate housing-related poverty and to ensure that housing assistance is, as far as possible, delivered equitably to persons resident in different forms of housing. Under the new agreement it is proposed that in each of the 10 years from 1 July 1989, Commonwealth financial assistance to the States under the. CSHA will be provided entirely in the form of grants, rather than as a mix of grants and concessional Loan Council moneys. Half of the States' matching effort will also be required to be met with grants. This will result in a major increase in real State effort and will ensure that States' ability to finance public rental housing will no longer be constrained by a burgeoning debt servicing obligation. In the five years ended 1988-89, State contributions made in the form of grants were only about one-tenth of the value of Commonwealth grant contributions. States have also agreed to absorb any future losses on their rental operations. From now on the great bulk of Commonwealth and State matching funds will be used for the direct provision of public rental dwellings. Based on 1989-90 funding levels we expect that the impact of these new arrangements will allow around 52,000 net additions to the public dwelling stock over the next five years. At the same time around 650,000 people will be able to be offered public rental housing, an increase of around 20 per cent on the past five years. This public housing effort will allow a greater focus on those in greatest housing very low income earners and social security recipients for whom home ownership is not an option. Prior to this agreement, a large proportion of Commonwealth funds was being provided through Loan Council borrowing arrangein ments. While adding to overall funds, Loan Council arrangements distorted the allocato tion of funds among States, so that the funds were not sufficiently targeted to areas highest need. For example, the Northern Territory received about half the level of funds received by New South Wales, in of the vast difference in population. This anomaly will be rectified under the new agreement. All funds will not be provided grants and their distribution among States will move to a per capita basis. This will be a major step in directing assistance to where that assistance is needed. The phasing in the per capital distribution over three years will allow States time to adjust their tions. The new agreement demonstrates our commitment to improving access to home this ownership for low income earners. States inefficient will continue to be able to draw on funds retained from past allocations to finance their general home purchase assistance programs. The net level of these funds is currently of the order of $360m. States are encouraged under the agreement to gear up these funds with private sector funds, to boost ance available. States' capacity to draw in private sector funds will also be expanded considerably as a result of our decision to clearly exempt such raisings from Loan people Council borrowing limits. This removes any uncertainty which existed in the past. A proportion of new CSHA funds also will be directed to home purchase programs from 1989-90 onwards and these will be geted to existing public tenants and applipeople cants on the waiting list. In addition States are able to meet the other half of their matching obligation with home purchase asconsulting sistance loans and this will add a further incentive for them to expand their programs. These changes will encourage a far more efficient use of funds than in the past and will allow States to considerably expand their home ownership lending programs by implementing innovative schemes to closely meet needthe needs of low income home buyers. Over the next five years we expect that around 200,000 low and middle income home buyers will receive home purchase loans under CSHA programs. This is a substantial increase on the 68,000 home loans provided the five years ended June 1988. Because repayments on CSHA home loans are linked income, this initiative will significantly boost access to affordable home ownership of for lower income earners. Assistance under the agreement is well targeted, and priority in granting assistance is determined by need. spite However, a key change will be made to existing administrative arrangements to ensure that we continue to meet these objecas tives, and improve our linking of public housing with other assistance programs. In the past States have been able to use general agreement funds without any referof ence to specific Commonwealth priorities or objectives. A new system of priority setting operawill be implemented unqer the agreement through the establishment of a joint Commonwealth-State planning process. Through process we are aiming to ensure, without duplication of administration, that the provision of public housing assistance remains in accord with the principles of the CSHA and responsive to the needs of people. It will focus on improving equality of access to appropriate accommodation and will ensure better coordination of public housing the assistprovision with other programs. It is envisaged that the development of Commonwealth-State plans will ensure that· the priorities of all groups, including youth, with disabilities, Aboriginals and the aged are met under public housing arrangements. There is a range of Commonwealth programs which need to be linked to public housing provision-for example, programs tarcovering accommodation for the aged and with disabilities-and the joint planning process will ensure this occurs. As part of the joint planning process we will be with community groups, to ensure a full range of views on public housing is taken into account. There is an increasing awareness in the community of consumer protection issues to uphold the dignity, independence and freedom of the individual, to preserve people's rights and to provide protection of those rights. The new agreement provides that information will be made available to clients about housing assistance and policies. In addition, independent appeal mechanisms are to be established in each State by September 1990. These initiatives link with our user rights strategies for service provision in the areas of aged care, supported accommodation and home care. The position of clients is to be further enhanced under the new agreement. The Commonwealth and States are to examine the issues of increasing choice of housing between public rental and home purchase assistance, portability of eligibility for assistance between States and improved maintenance arrangements. This Government has backed up the new arrangements with funds. In 1989-90, for the first time, over $1 billion will be made a vailable in grants under the agreement. Furthermore, the Commonwealth Government will guarantee at least this level-$1.028 billionfor each of the three years 1990-91 to 199293. Total funding for those years will be determined annually in the Budget context. This $4 billion guarantee is unprecedented and shows this Government's determination to deliver on its social justice commitments in housing. The Bill also provides for two further appropriations in 1989-90-$9.8m will be appropriated for specific grants to the States and the Northern Territory for housing assistance for young people. These funds form part of our social justice package for young Australians which is part of the response to the problems highlighted in the Burdekin report on youth homelessness. The funds will be used to provide accommodation linked to support services for homeless young people. This will help them become more independent and guide them to longer term stable accommodation. An amount of $14.7m will also be appropriated to provide additional mortgage relief . funds. These funds will be provided to the States and the Northern Territory to assist low and moderate income earners who are experiencing difficulty in meeting their mortgage commitments. These funds were earmarked in the Budget and are additional to those already provided through the mortgage and rent relief scheme. The Commonwealth Government is committed to housing access, and to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The structural reforms embodied in the new agreement together with the substantial increase in funding and forward commitment for future years will significantly enhance our public housing effort. Based on current funding, over the next five years we expect to see around 650,000 people offered public rental dwellings, 52,000 additions to the public rental stock and around 200,000 home loans provided to low and moderate income families. I believe that we will be able to make significant inroads in alleviating housing related poverty in 1989-90 and over the 10 years of the agreement. We will also see improved public housing effort by all parties to the agreement, better targeting of assistance to high need areas, improved choice of assistance and more open, accessible and responsive administration. I commend the Bill to the House. I now present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr MCGauran) adjourned. NA 1989 Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time. Title: MARINE NAVIGATION LEVY BILL
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to alter the basis of calculating the method of charging commercial shipowners for the navigational services provided to them by the Commonwealth. The Bill will also transfer the authority to raise the necessary revenue from the Lighthouses Act 1911 to a levy Act and its associated collection Act. This will remove any doubt that may exist as to the constitutional validity of light dues as a method of cost recovery. Since 1915, the Commonwealth has operated an extensive network of marine navigational aids around the coast of Australia to facilitate the safe and economic navigation of vessels engaged in trade and commerce .. This network, which presently numbers some 387 navigational aids, costing about $39m per year, is fully financed by light paid by commercial shipping engaged on both overseas and coastal trading. The rate of light dues is 53c per Inet registered tonne of the vessel per quarter. The rate is the same regardless of the flag of the vessel or the trade engaged upon. Through the efficient rationalisation of the system and the effective use of modern technology, the rate of light dues has not been increased since October 1983. This represents a considerable reduction in real costs to the shipping indusbut try. It has been achieved despite some signifreduced icant investment in recent years, including Hydrographers Passage in the Great Barrier Reef and on the north-west coast of Australia. These investments have been primarily for the benefit of the bulk export trade in those areas. The commercial shipping industry is closely consulted on all matters relating to the operations of the navigational aids network through the Maritime Services Advisory Committee on Navigational Safety. There are representatives of both foreign and Australian flag shipowners on this Committee. In recent years, the increasing complexity and variety of navigational services and aids provided to ships, and the increasing disparity between the ships themselves and .the trades on which they are engaged, have thrown considerable doubt on the validity of the traditional charging methods. Two years ago, therefore, the Government initiated an examination of the basis of charging light dues. The new rates of levy contained in the levy Bill now before the House result from that examination. Although various alternative methods of charging were considered, no practicable method of charging in terms of cargo values or use of individual aids was discovered. A levy based on the net tonnage of a ship was found to be the fairest of the practicable methods. It was considered that some variation in the formula for setting dues might be feasible and consultations were started immediately with the shipping industry. It was also decided that the existing exemptions for naval vessels, fishing craft and private yachts should continue. During the extensive consultations with industry groups, a wide variety of options was considered. As would be expected with such a diverse. range of interdues ests, it proved impossible to reach a full consensus on the most appropriate formula to apply. Nevertheless, in June this year, as part of the overall reforms of maritime and waterfront activities, the Government was able to announce the new formula preferred by a clear majority of industry representatives. Under the new formula, the rate per net tonne is reduced as the ship's tonnage increases. Smaller vessels will pay slightly more the large vessels will pay significantly amounts each year. This will be of in particular benefit to the larger bulk ore carriers which carry, i in terms of tonnage, the greater part of our exports. The new levy is based on a sliding scale which ranges from 33 to 63c per net registered tonne compared with the present 53c per tonne and will continue to be paid each quarter. To illustrate, a small coastal vessel of 200 tonnes will pay some $20 per quarter more; a vessel of 25,000 tonnes will pay the same as now; and a 72,000 tonne vessel will pay some $6,900 per quarter less. These represent significant on-going savings to the large bulk carriers serving our export trades. The levy Bill imposes the levy in accordance with the formula I referred to earlier. It also allows the rate of levy to be varied by regulation. However, to prevent the levy being increased by regulation to a level beyond that represented by reasonable cost increases, a ceiling of 15 per cent per annum has been imposed. To summarise, Mr Speaker, this Bill and its associated collection Bill bring up to date the method of charging for the provision by the Commonwealth of navigation aids and related navigational services. While I cannot say that every sector of the shipping community agrees wholeheartedly with the formula arrived at, I can say that it represents the best compromise that could be reached. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
