Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: 1 join other speakers in this debate in supporting the Grape Research Levy Amendment Bill, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. 1I have noticed throughout the debate that honourable members who have wineries and grape growers in their electorates have continually referred to the issue of whether the wineries in their electorates are the best in Australia. My friend the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) resisted the temptation of saying that. As the wineries in his electorate are very close to the wineries in my electorate, 1 can shall not resist that temptation. The wineries in the Southern Vales and at Langhorne Creek and the new developing wineries in the Adelaide Hills are certainly the best wineries in Australia. Some magnificent wines are produced in my electorate and I am proud to represent the wine industry in that part of Australia. As others have said in this debate, these Bills restructure the levy for the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, and in doing so will no doubt increase the amount of revenue that the Corporation is able to obtain from the industry for the rUlming of its various functions. They also change the labelling regulations in order to improve the integrity of labelling within the Australian wine industry. Members of the House have strongly supported these propositions. We obviously want to see the integrity of the AustraliaR wine industry enhanced as much as possible. Many people in the industry have been concerned about scandals that have broken out both in Australia, and in particular outside Australia, which have affected the integrity of the industry. 1 recall at one stage a scandal relating to the Austrian wine industry which had some impact on sales from Australia because of the similarity of the names in English. 1 think that points to the importance of ensuring that our industry has a strong reputation for a high level of integrity. It does have that reputation but improved labelling and a tightening up of regulations in regard to labelling will certainly help to build that reputation. Others before me have said that the Wine and Brandy Corporation plays an important part in the process in particular of marketing Australian wines overseas and also administering some aspects of the industry in Australia. There is no doubt that the Corporation has come a very long way from the position of its predecessor in the 1960s when I used to live in the United Kingdom. The predecessor of the Corporation had a wine shop in Frith Street in Soho and that was about the only contribution it made to the export of Australian wines. Mr Hand-What were you doing in Soho?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs wonders what I was doing in Soho. In the 1960s I was only a young teenager, so I was not too much in Soho. But, of course, that is digressing from the central thrust of the debate. The point is that the predecessor of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation had its shop in Soho and many Australians were anxious to ensure that our industry was properly promoted. Probably in that location it was not. The sale of wine such as Kanga Rouge and the like certainly did not do anything. to enhance the reputation of the Australian wine industry. In those days there was also a practice of exporting only the unwanted product rather than our best products and, therefore, building up a strong market. Obviously that strategy failed. The strategy is the reverse now and it is certainly turning out to be a very successful one in the Corporation. But, of course, above all, the industry deserves a great deal of support and commendation from this Parliament for the work that it has done. The wine industry has faced a large number of vicissitudes over recent years and some of those vicissitudes have been induced by the Government. I can remember very well back in the time of the 1983 Federal election campaign when the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) came to what is now part of my electorate, but which was then part of the marginal electorate of Kingston, to the town of MCLaren Vale. In MCLaren Vale the present Minister made a speech on behalf of the Australian Labor Party saying that no wine tax would be imposed by the Labor Party. This sentiment was warmly endorsed by the then Labor candidate for Kingston, the present honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), and it was not long before the 10 per cent wine tax was first introduced, despite this promise that was made to the electors of MCLaren Vale who, I am glad to say, did not fall for this promise then and have not fallen for any promises from the Labor Party since and probably never will. Nevertheless, it was a cynical exercise, a commitment overturned within weeks or months of its being made, and the wine tax was not only introduced at 10 per cent but subsequently increased to 20 per cent. At the time that caused a great deal of concern in the industry. Even today there is no doubt that the imposition of a wine tax has affected the relative competitiveness of the industry as against, for example, beer. But, as the industry well recognises now, the wine tax is here to stay and I guess that the debate on the wine tax is a debate of yesterday. It is important to remember that a commitment was once made in an election campaign, in what is now my electorate, and that commitment was soon overturned. That is an example of the sort of government-induced vicissitudes that the wine industry has had to put up with. Another was the introduction by the present Government of its much lauded vine pull scheme. This was introduced at a time when prices were not particularly buoyant in the industry and the growers were enduring a great deal of difficulty, so the Government decided that it would spend taxpayers' money to induce those growers to rip out their vines. No sooner had they ripped out their vines than the industry went through an upturn and, of course, there were not enough grapes and the price of grapes very rapidly rose. So the vine pull scheme was a good example of government intervention in a market, which caused precisely the wrong effect. We needed increased production to help meet growing new markets, in particular overseas, and at the time the Government was paying taxpayers' money to people to pull out the vines. It really was a very curious scheme and it has had some long term consequences in some parts of the Southern Vales of South Australia. After enduring those vicissitudes there is no doubt that, in recent years, the wine industry has done substantially better. I think everyone would agree that the export market has been the key to that improvement in the performance of the industry. In 1986-87 and 1987-88 exports from the wine industry, in volume terms, grew by about 30 per cent per annum and, in value terms, exports have grown over those two years by around 120 per cent, which really is a magnificent record for the industry. Things were not so good in 1988-89, but still the value of the exports improved by 15 per cent and, in volume, by 3 per cent. As others have said in this debate, we now have an industry which exports $1l3.3m worth of \\fine and there is no question that that makes a contribution to the balance of payments. We now export one per cent of the world's wine export market. While that figure of one per cent does not sound particularly sensational, we have a right to be proud of the way our wine industry has got into those export markets and has successfully obtained a market niche. When we go to countries such as the United States of America, or to different parts' of Europe-I suppose that one could say in particular Sweden-or to Japan, there is no question that Australian wine is increasingly highly regarded and we have to ensure that it remains so. There is no doubt that this package of legislation will make a contribution to that. I note with some interest that the amount of assistance that the Government gives to the wine through Austrade-if we disregard the sort of negative assistance that was once provided through things like the vine pull scheme-is about $100,000 a year. This is $100,000 worth of assistance to an industry with export earnings of $113m. I am not a big supporter of the Government giving assistance to different industries and I am not here today calling for massive increases in government assistance to help the wine industry and export markets; I do not think that is the way to go at all. But it is interesting just to make a comparison here. The Government gives $100,000 worth of assistance to the wine industry, which has total exports of $113m, whereas, by contrast, Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, which has exports of $175m, has been blessed by the Government with $12m a year for three years. I assume from that that the Government's priority is for cameras and films rather than for the Australian wine industry. It seems to me that that represents a very curious set of priorities on the part of the Government. As I have said, I would rather the Government did not provide assistance to Kodak and I do not think there is a great case for the Government to pour money into promoting Australian wine exports because the industry, through the operation of the Corporation and this levy, is able to do that job quite adequately without the so-called assistance of government. But, if the Government thinks that cameras and films are more important than the wine industry and the employment that goes with it, it has a very strange set of priorities. Of course, at the domestic level the wine industry has not had anything like the glamorous record that it has had in export markets over recent years. For example, in 198889, wine sales fell by 6.9 per cent and the bulk of the burden of that decline in wine sales has fallen on the cask wine sector-the sector which is particularly prominent in my State of South Australia, although I would have to say not in my own electorate. It is interesting to note that the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation points to the imposition of the wine tax as being one of the factors which have affected the domestic market and I have alluded to that already. But one of the other factors is the change in the beer excise arrangements which were introduced by the Government in the 1988-89 Budget. The brewing industry has always argued that it should be on a level playing field with the wine industry and I am sympathetic to that; I think we should have a level playing field in our economy, including the area of beverages, be they alcoholic or non-alcoholic. But the fact is that the beer industry has always argued that, because there was no sales tax, the wine industry has done particularly well. The sales tax has been introduced and, suddenly, we saw that the beer excise was slashed in a desperate bid by the Government to try to win back what is sometimes described as its traditional support, although I suspect that the way things are going today there is no longer such a thing as traditional support for the Labor Party. One of the consequences of the slashing of the beer excise has been that increasingly people have moved from purchasing casks to purchasing light beer. Clearly, the level playing field is not as level as it used to be. Before the changes to the beer excise, wine had a relative 12 per cent discount compared with beer and now wine has a relative 9 per cent premium compared with beer. That means the playing field is one which favours beer as distinct from wine. I suppose that reflects the political priorities of the Government. It takes the view, which mayor may not be right, that Labor voters are more likely to favour the drinking of beer than the drinking of wine and that Liberal voters are more likely to favour the drinking of wine than the drinking of beer. That seems a fairly curious hypothesis, but that seems to be the principle on which it is working. Therefore, it stings the wine drinkers and favours the beer drinkers. What we need is a level playing field, not a playing field which favours one as against the other simply for party political purposes, particularly as a response to the debacles of the Port Adelaide and Adelaide by-elections. Other factors are affecting the wine industry. There is no doubt that the pilots strike is having some impact at the top end of the market in the wine industry. This was referred to by Wolf Blass, a distinguished South Australian vigneron, in his recent annual report. He pointed out that the restaurant trade has inevitably suffered because of the pilots strike. That can be seen in my electorate and throughout Adelaide. Obviously the effects on the restaurant trade flow through to the wine industry. Wine sales are down as a consequence of the pilots strike. It is important to make that point to those people who do not think that the pilots strike is having any effect, that it does not matter very much, or, even more alarmingly, that apparenUy it is over. They need to be reminded that the wine industry is an example of an industry which is directly affected by that dispute. I make no apology for referring to it as a dispute. Other costs are clearly affecting the wine market. The high price of the Australian dollar, which is propped up artificially by the Government's high interest rate strategy, makes exports more expensive and imports cheaper. If exports are more expensive it is unlikely that all our balance of payments problems will be resolved. I would have thought that that is a fairly logical and rational way of looking at things. Obviously it will have some impact on the capacity of the wine industry to maintain the growth that it has managed to obtain in export markets. The latest figures seem to support that. Some people in the wine industry say that wine prices for Australian exported wine are such that export markets must inevitably come to an end. It will be sad if that happens. One of the reasons it has the potential to happen is the high level of interest rates. Because of consumer demand overseas for Australian wine-I do not know that I feel too badly about this-grape prices have been forced up. This year they are expected to increase by 35 per cent. I am glad about that in this respect: many grape growers in my electorate will do very well out of it. I know many of them extremely well. They have been through some very hard times and at last they are going through significantly easier times because of the increasing grape prices. One of the reasons grape prices have increased so much is a shortage of stock. One of the reasons there is a shortage of stock is the extraordinary vine pull scheme. The Government decided that it would provide an incentive to rip vines out of the ground. As a consequence, we have a - ack of supply at a time when there is a fairly buoyant market. It just shows that; if governments keep out of markets instead of continually trying to second guess the way markets operate, we might end up with an economy that runs more smoothly. I do not say that out of any disrespect for those in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy who are responsible for these matters. I know that some very able people work in that part of the Department. But there is no doubt that it is better to let the industry take its own course than be interfered with by government action. Turning to the taxation arrangements for the wine industry, I refer to stock valuation and the depreciation of oak casks. Some time ago there was a significant debate about stock valuation. We on this side of the House-I refer particularly to me and my South Australian colleagues-put together a submission to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) asking him to reconsider the stock valuation situation. The Government was most derisory about that, I suppose because the proposal had come from the Liberal Party. What we wanted to do, again, was make sure that there was a level playing field so the wine industry was able to obtain the same depreciation advantages as other industries in Australia. There was a fairly heated debate about that. For one reason or another that debate has died down and the industry has looked more to obtaining some greater degree of depreciation for oak casks as an option to ensure that its costs are properly recognised in the taxation system. Until now the depreciation rates on oak casks have allowed depreciation over a period of 10 years. I note, because I do not think that this is known very widely, that the Australian Taxation office has now agreed to a 25 per cent per annum depreciation of oak casks. Clearly, this will be of significant benefit to the wine industry. We have been able to obtain those improved tax arrangements for the wine industry because South Australian Liberal members of both Houses of this Parliament, as well as the shadow Minister for primary industry-the honourable member . for Murray and Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr L1oyd)-have gone out and fought for a better taxation deal for the wine industry. We have not gone out and argued for special exemptions and deals which would apply only to the wine industry and which would bias the market towards the wine industry. We have gone out and argued for a level playing field. We have argued for the wine industry to have a fair go in terms of the taxation system. It is because we have made that and promoted it as a political issue that finally the Australian Taxation Office has been forced to review the whole question of the taxation of the wine industry and has taken the very constructive initiative of changing the depreciation rates on oak casks. Our wine industry is a great Australian industry of which we all have a right to be proud. I am particularly proud of the wineries and grape growers in my electorate who have done such a magnificent job for that part of South Australia. I am particularly proud of what my State has done as the wine capital of Australia. I hope that these measures, which are supported by both sides of the House, will enhance the prospects of the wine industry in the years ahead.

Title: NOES
text: I am able to announce on behalf of the Opposition that we will be supporting these education Bills, I am able to do that because we have an Economic Action Plan, We have a very clear set of policy commitments in respect of education, What a contrast that is to the chaos and confusion on the other side of the House in respect of economic policy, The Government is incapable of making a clear statement on its ability to address Australia's economic problems, If ever a plan ignited the blowtorch to the soft underbelly of our opponents, it was certainly the Economic PAIRS Action Plan announced recently by the  behalf of the Opposition, This week we have had the extraordinary spectacle of the Government in chaos. We had a pathetic performance from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), That was symbolic of the problems announced by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) this. week, when he let loose the Government's plans for the forthcoming election. The. Opposition has policy positions in spect of higher education, technical and further education (TAFE) and schools. I take this opportunity in this wide ranging debate on education to canvass some of those issues. These Bills provide funding on an annual basis and supplementation for those three sectors. In this debate, I am pleased to have the support of a number of Opposition members: the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who has particular concerns as a representative of the Gold Coast area, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who has a particular interest in education and who will be speaking in this debate, and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who has a particular interest in Aboriginal affairs issues, just to mention a few. Whilst I will be speaking mainly on schools and higher education, let me say that we support the T AFE legislation. The Commonwealth has a limited role in technical and further education and a limited role in recurrent funding, in the order of 8 per cent. It has a greater role in capital funding, two-thirds of capital requirements. J am pleased to say that the Opposition supports the continued provision of Commonwealth funds for T AFE and principlesupplementation. We will maintain, in real terms,' Commonwealth financial assistance for T AFE, that is, the total of present recurrent, plus present capital, assistance. We have a detailed policy position on T AFE. I am looking forward to the implementation of that policy in its entirety. The Opposition is pleased to see the Government making some moves in respect of student assistance, belated though they may be, to reduce fraud in student assistance schemes. In fact, the Opposition has been on the Government's back about this matter for a number of years. When I held the shadow Attorney-General's portfolio, we were very concerned about what we believed to be the widespread occurrence of fraud against the Commonwealth. We have had some action from the Commonwealth in this area with a committee to review fraud, but it is our view that this whole issue ought to be taken further, that the Government ought to be more precise and more determined in pursuing fraud. I think it is common ground that there re- is something of a culture amongst the student population with respect to fraud. Obviously, that needs to be addressed. I think it was Mark Twain who once said, 'You can be on the right track but if you happen to be stationary you will still be run over by the next train'. Whilst this measure is on the right track, going in the right direction, we say that it is one of those issues where we could be moving-and the Government should be moving-at a faster pace. In dealing with the issue, we have, not just sat back and made generalised calls for action on the Government's part. I refer to my earlier interest in this issue. In 1987, under a Federal freedom of information application, we extracted from the Government a report by Price Waterhouse on fraud. One of the interesting things about that report is that it said-in a sense, not surprisingly-that if you are going to address this problem, the first thing you should do is look to, and make some calculation about, the total level of fraud. If you do not know how prevalent the problem is,· it is a bit hard to know how about many dollars, how much in the way of resources, you should pour into combat the problem. That has not been resolved to our satisfaction. We believe that that is one of a number of steps that should be taken. In July this year I announced, on behalf of the coalition, a five-point plan to achieve some savings in this area. We press that on the Government. In fact, it was just one small but important feature of the Leader of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, a comprehensive document which addresses Australia's economic problems. The Economic Action Plan has five points: firstly, the adoption of the Price Waterhouse recommendation to quantify the level of fraud; secondly, administrative arrangements for vetting Austudy applications tightened; thirdly, the adoption of a system to check all Austudy recipients on a regular basis; fourthly, the Government should, as a matter of' policy, give high priority to fraud investigation, prosecution and recovery action; and, finally, the Auditor-General should be requested to undertake a thorough audit of Austudy. We are pleased to support the measures proposed in the legislative package, but would prefer to see the Government have the sense to adopt our five-point plan. It interesting that there has been a lot of dement. bate about this Economic Action Plan. Of course, the Government attempted to attack it and put out a list of what the coalition proposed and what the Department of Fidiscussion nance thought was a fair thing. If one looks at our proposals in respect of fraud, one can see that we would save $30m by tightening up in that area, and we had the endorsement of the Department of Finance. We thank It the Department for giving us that endorseAs ment. It shows that more should be done, and we urge that on the Government. I turn now to the question of overseas 1992. students. The coalition supports the introduction of full fees for overseas students. However, we draw attention to the anomaly that exists whereby qualified students overseas can come to Australia and buy education but, by contrast, an Australian student cannot do the same thing. There is an unmet demand. No-one is sure of the exact figure but there are many Australian students-about 14,000, 20,000 or a figure that order-who are qualified to go to uniment, versity but are denied a place. What a strange anomaly it is that we as a society and community say, 'Well, if you .. come from overseas and you are prepared to pay we will find you a place-no problem.' In fact, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) supports that and encourages it-and so do we, I might add; this country. there are no problems about that. However, when it comes to our students-people who are born and bred in this country and have a stake in the future of this countryport the Government says no. Of course, it is purely political, ideological reasons, and condemn the Government for adopting that policy position. I will pick up one other issue in respect of overseas students, and it is something that we have raised with the Department. I refer to the proposal to extend the overseas dent charge to primary school students. We asked a question as to how that would affect the children of diplomatic and other overseas personnel in Australia, but we have not yet heard a complete response. I do not think it is a party political debate between the coawe lition and the Government: it is a matter that should be looked at, and we look foris ward to hearing a response from the GovernI turn now to schools policy, a critical area for debate and a critical policy area which I think will be the subject of a lot of between now and the next election as people look to make a choice between the political parties. We on this side of the House have a very clear policy commitment. I have a copy of the policy here. spells out our position in black and white. I say, that allows me to respond to this legislation. It is in contrast to the Government's position on funding for schools postAn options paper has been circulated. I am always happy to support consultative mechanisms but we await the production of from the post-1992 funding policy from the an Government. We wait to see whether the gathering clouds of the blunder from the Minister for Social Security earlier this week will come across the top of the policy to threaten the Government's expenditure comof mitments. We have a watertight commitat a minimum, to maintain funding to schools. We guarantee that no school or a school system, government or non-government, will be worse off on a per capita basis than currently. We support the concept of the partnership between the government and non-government school authorities in providing quality education for young people in We have an equally firm commitment to ensure that every Australian child receives a who reasonable measure of Commonwealth suptowards his or her education and to for ensure that parents have real freedom of we choice about which school will be best for their children. To that end we propose a new recurrent funding regime for nongovernment schools. We will reduce the current 12 categories of funding to four categories with a basic per capita grant of 20 per stucent of the cost of a government school place. That figure will be calculated in an open and public way so that people know what we base our funding commitment upon. The basic minimum level will be 20 per cent. We say that people who exercise freedom of choice to send.. their children to a nongovernment school ought to be able to look to government and to say, 'We would like just a small portion of our taxes back to support that freedom of choice to send our children to the school of our choice'. We say that 20 per cent is a fair figure. That figure takes us back to where we were in approximately 1983. We see that as a fundamental commitment in contrast to the backsliding that we, get from the Government on this issue. It is a firm, clear commitment so that people know where they stand and so that they can be satisfied and sure that there will be no backing off from that commitment. Our commitment is to provide funding of 20 per cent, rising for the three other categories to 30 per cent, 40 per cent and 50 per cent of the cost of a government school place, depending upon the existing categorisation. By having that funding regime we have a system which addresses this whole problem of supplementation. With our system the Government's funding commitment has a clear nexus to the cost of running a government school place. With that system and with changes that will be seen throughout the economy and reflected in the costs of running a government school, people in non-government schools can be certain that they will not have their funding allocation from governments eroded. In addition to having this nice, clear, firm commitment about recurrent funding, we will address one of the other major issues in respect of schools policy: we will abolish Labor's new schools policy. It is a policy of containment. It is not just about new schools. The wording in this policy is a great way to mislead people as to what it is all about. The Government calls it a new schools policy but an old school can be a new school, just to give you the flavour of it, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is a policy which restricts growth of the non-government schools sector. It places a ceiling, a cap, on the growth of nongovernment school enrolments. We say that that is wrong as a matter of principle and we will abolish it. It is an area of some embarrassment for the Government in that it has this policy commitment but every now and then we find that, when it does not suit the Government, it just dumps it. We support non-government schools-for example, Alphington Grammar School in Melbourne. Under the Opposition's policy there is no question about a permit. Under Labor's new schools policy people have to come to Canberra for a permit. We should abolish that system. Looking at how the Government operates, we find that Alphington Grammar, a Greek community school, wanted a permit from this crowd. Interestingly, the school did not comply with the Government's criteria, so a bit of political pressure was applied and, suddenly, it was back in with the permit. It still has funding problems, but that is another issue. Those Government members who argue the benefits of the new schools policy might like also to argue the justification of its dumping for the purest political reasons, as has been evidenced on a number of occa,sions in Victoria. text: Let me put the honourable member's mind at rest: for those students who do not have $1,200 cash there will be a provision of a government guarantee to allow them to obtain an appropriate loan. I should now like briefly to say something about amalgamations, because I think this is the sharp end of Labor's policies in respect of higher education. As to the question of amalgamation, it is made possible by the Minister's very clear policy position, which is that, if an organisation does not do as it is told, then he will place the squeeze on it in terms of funding. I think the Minister's conduct in relation to a number of these amalgamations has been nothing short of outrageous. The honourable member opposite is from Perth, and he ought to take an interest. The way that the Government has gone in respect of the University of Western Australia (AWU) and Murdoch University is not in the best interests of either institution. Any member, whether on this side of the House or on the opposite side of the House, ought to be concerned about the way in which the Minister goes on. His comments are amazingly blatant. In his speech he says: These funds will allow the Government to make early decisions on new capital projects to commence in 1992 . . . Many of these' capital projects will take into account mergers which have occurred, or are occurring, in many parts of the country. In other words, they will take into account' the bribes and threats that the Minister has been making all over the country since last year in his effort to enforce his program of reform, a program which has met with a great deal of opposition, for very good reasons. Blatantly, he offers the special goody, the $17m to the institutions in his home town of Perth. Murdoch and the UWA have been dutifully in line with the Minister's requirements for months but, not surprisingly, given the difficulties and the feelings that have arisen as a result, the Minister now has the prospect of contesting his own seat in Fremantle against a Murdoch student who felt so strongly about the damage being caused to the institution where he is studying that he chose to enter politics. This is not just a view expressed by those on this side. Dr Carmen Lawrence, the Minister for Education in the west, has been pretty vocal, to the embarrassment of the Government, in the higher education supplement of the Australian, attacking the Minister for his centralising policy position. The honourable member for Perth ought to take some notice of it. I think we see some real ambivalence from Dr Lawrence about this merger, this proposal. We have not seen her Bill. There is a draft floating around. In the end we will oppose it in the upper House because there is no educational or financial benefit to be derived from it. There is a long list of similar situations. I am very concerned about the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT). The Minister had a meeting there last Friday. He said to officials at the RMIT, 'If you don't play ball, then I will put a cap on your student enrolments. I will place a freeze on your capital funding and furthermore I will take the Western institute and Footscray Institute of Technology and make them the fifth university in Victoria and you can go and sit on the shelf'. By any objective assessment that is a most unreasonable way in which to proceed. The people at RMIT are only concerned about one thing-that is, that they have built up a first class institution over 100 years and this Minister has a manic determination to get his own way. He is prepared to sacrifice one of the great tertiary institutions of this country just to get his political policy position intq place. That is not good enough. I encourage and commend those people at RMIT to stand up against these bully tactics because that is all that they are. I simply say to them that upon the change in government, which will soon be upon us, they will get a fair deal from us, as they should. It is as simple as that. Finally, let me touch on one other matter which has been raised recently by the Minister. I think it is one of the most incredible proposals put forward by a Minister for many years. This Minister has done more to undermine the autonomy and independence of our institutions than any other Minister. As I said, we have experts from one end of the country to the other making that very point. I refer to people such as Professor Karmel. Is the honourable member for Perth going to stand and deny his experience and the value of ,his commentary on the situation? Of course not. Would he stand and deny the views of someone such as Professor Caro, a former Vice-Chancellor of Melbourne University? Of course he would not because what is being said by these people in our tertiary institutions is that the Minister and the Government are destroying one of the great qualities of our universities and are placing at risk and in jeopardy the future of those institutions. The Minister comes along and says, 'All will be well. We'll have a charter of academic freedom'. That is the classic case. That is the arsonist standing back watching the fire rage and saying, 'She'll be right, I'll call the fire cart'. It is a very sorry tale when we analyse the details of this Government's actions in respect of higher education. I am afraid to say that the ramifications of this Minister's manic determination to put the unified national system into place will be with us for many years. Some of the antagonisms that have been created between institutions will be with us for many years, regardless of goodwill, and I condemn him for it. Debate (on motion by Dr Charlesworth) adjourned. Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Corangamite) (7.45)I rise t'onight in response to recent discussions I have had with Professor Brian Start from the Education Department at Melbourne University concerning the plight of gifted and talented children in our community. Despite the very damning conclusions drawn by the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children, the Federal Government has steadfastly ignored the issue of further financial assistance for gifted and talented children. It is a matter of great concern to me that this Government's social agenda is so programmed as to curtail severely the pursuit of excellence by such children in our community. While those identified as having learning difficulties have been greatly assisted to achieve their full potential, this Government has blatantly denied the same attention, support and right of those with above average intelligence to a challenging education. My recent discllssions with Professor Start, who is also the Foundation Director of Children of High Intellectual Potential, or CHIP, have given me a valuable guide as to the misallocation of resources presently occurring, to the detriment of gifted children in the community. For example, for everyone hour spent training those who will teach them, 20 hours are spent on the teachers of retarded children. For every dollar earmarked for their education and enrichment, thousands of dollars go to the handicapped. In Victoria alone $61m is spent annually on the handicapped. This compares with the $180,000 spent on gifted and talented children. The Senate report itself states clearly that if priorities for resources must be determined among educationally disadvantaged groups, it could be argued that gifted children are currently among the most disadvantaged of these groups. If we in Australia accept the United Nations declaration that every child should be given the chance to develop his or her potential on the basis of equal opportunity-if it is considered desirable in Australia that provision should be made for all children to fully develop their abilities-it follows that this must be true not only for average and/or disabled children but also for gifted children. Surely, if our education system aims to cater for disadvantaged and average learners it has also the responsibility to make adequate provision for those in the community who are endowed with special talents. Clearly, this Government should be about providing equally for all children at both ends of the spectrum. Its present attitude is discriminatory and merely designed to perpetuate the myth that gifted children are elite and can look after themselves. While they may be intellectually talented, they have a right to the same sort of support that is offered to the disadvantaged. It is a national disgrace that the present Government denies them the right to an education benefiting their intellectual abilities. Its hi.dden social agenda is aimed directly at frustrating those in our community with natural talent and ability. We in the coalition stand for the rights of all children-disadvantaged, average and exceptional-to an education benefiting them as individuals. The Chairman of the Committee of Inquiry into Education in Western Australia, the Hon. Kim Beazley Sr, in an address to the first national conference on the education of gifted and talented children in Melbourne in 1983, observed quite correctly that: . special adjustments to the education of the gifted should not be regarded as something abnormal, but part of the courtesy and grace due to every child. In refusing to acknowledge and support the talents of the gifted, this Government is actively pursuing social and intellectualdivisiveness on the basis of individual ability. Discouraging the pursuit of excellence is typical of its plans for creating a sort of level playing field on which individual human behaviour is discouraged and stifled in the spurious name of social justice. In talking about gifted and talented children we are not talking about children who are clever. We are talking about children with the ability and potential to perform at a level far above their peers at the same age. We are talking about children who at the age of eight years have gained a maths result that places them ahead of almost every 18year-old college entrant in Australia; about a 14-year-old who could have had a bachelor of science degree to add to his credentials; and about a 12-year-old who was offered a place at Oxford University in England be': cause our education system could not cope with the logistical problems her case presented. Professor Start submitted in evidence to the Senate Committee: The gifted will produce far more than they consume. This country has an enviable record of caring for the disabled. But let's face it, the cure for Down's Syndrome won't be coming from a child with that problem. But it may come from one of these gifted children. They are our greatest national resource. My recent involvement with the sports funding subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has led me to the conclusion that there is a definite imbalance in Australia in the way in which resources and attention are given to those with natural talent in the sporting arena and even in the arts arena compared with what is given to those who are gifted.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to pay a compliment to a fine Northern Territory family and particularly a member of that family who is an outstanding pianist and a credit to her family and the Australian community. I am extremely proud to be able to acknowledge the efforts of Cindy Shin-Tain Chen, who was born in Taiwan in 1964 and came to Australia in 1977. Cindy is the daughter of Mr John Chen and his wife Shi-Liang and she has a sister Rachel. Cindy is an award winning pianist. She has been accepted as a student of piano into the Moscow State Conservatory for nine months from September 1990 as part of the Australian-Soviet Union cultural and academic exchange program. While she is in the Soviet Union, the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will take care of all costs, with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade meeting Cindy's travel costs. I am pleased to have been able to assist Cindy and her family through representations to the Soviet Embassy and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I would like to thank the officials in both the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Soviet Embassy for their help and assistance. Cindy is a credit to the virtues of the Australian immigration system. She has, as an Australian, been able to develop her extraordinary talent and will now act as an ambassador in the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics for the Northern Territory and Australia. Cindy matriculated in the Northern Territory in 1981 and was admitted to the University of Queensland in 1982. In that year, she was awarded a scholarship by the Northern Territory Government to undertake a bachelor of music degree at the University of Queenshlnd. During her tertiary studies she majored in piano perforII) ance with Bevan Crabtree and briefly with Pamela Page. In 1984 Cindy was awarded the Beta Sigma Phi prize for performance in piano and the Margaret Nickson prize for voice and accompaniment. She graduated in December 1985 with an honours degree in music. Cindy has performed in lunch hour recitals and has played in numerous civic concerts and she is also a very keen music educator. Currently, Cindy is appointed by the University of Queensland as an accompanist. Cindy Chen is a tribute to the excellence that can be obtained through the education system in Australia. I have known the Chen family since they came to Australia. John, Cindy's father, came via Timor in 1975 as a result of the conflagration and the invasion of that country by Indonesia. After John obtained his visa he applied to bring his wife and daughters from Taiwan, and they arrived in February 1977. In that same year, John Chen tutored me in Mandarin. As I have said before in this House, this is a tribute to the multicultural nature of the Northern Territory community. It is very important to acknowledge the role of students such as Cindy Chen and, in this case, the Chinese community in the Northern Territory for what they contribute to the Northern Territory community and the Australian community. Cindy is in a position to contribute a great deal to this country, as I am sure the House will acknowledge.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Since the introduction of the Budget, a constant theme with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has been in real trouble today, has been to claim that there was a serious lack of private investment in the 10 to 15 years prior to the advent of the Hawke Government and to blame this lack of investment for the present vast balance of payments deficit. As evidence for his claim, he frequently refers to Table 7 of Statement No.2 in Budget Paper No.1 at page 2.39. I would like to table a copy of that, along with one other paper that I shall mention in a moment. The table is a politicised phoney. The table purports to show, in columns 2 and 3, that over two five-year periods spanning the former Liberal-National Party Government, investment grew at only one or 2 per cent a year whereas, over the last five years, under the Hawke Government, there was strong growth of from 7 per cent to more than 10 .per cent a year. However, that is a bad case of 'damned lies and statistics'. The only valid comparison is between the five years of Liberal-National Party Government to 1981-82, when the economy came off the boil, and the past five years, with the economy again about to fall into recession, thereby comparing like with like in terms of the cycle of the economy. On that basis, going back to the original figures for investment-and I attach those figures as the second paper for tabling-the growth rate of private fixed investment to 1981-82 was nearly 8 per cent a year, not one or 2 per cent as the phoney table purports to show. That growth took place under a Liberal-National Party Government. Further, investment as a proportion of gross domestic product was 15.7 per cent in the beginning year, rising to about 19 per cent in 1981-82-hardly what one would call poor or no investment, as the Treasurer has often said. Under the present Government-again I refer honourable members to that second paper-the growth rate of investment was 7 per cent a year for the five years to 1987-88 or 8.5 per cent to 1988-89 when the effects of the recent investment uplift substantially affects the outcome. Investment as a proportion of gross domestic product rose from 15.8 per cent, almost identical to the earlier experience, to 17.5 per cent in 1987-88 or 20 per cent in 1988-89. Thus the aggregate outcome is broadly similar to the earlier periodabout 8 per cent per annum' growth in investment in both periods and rising from about 16 per cent to about 20 per cent of GDP over the cycle. Therefore, the Treasurer's repeated statements about poor or no investment prior to the Hawke Government are totally without foundation, as with many of this Treasurer's statements. Further, there can be no doubt that in the 1980-82 period there was more of the right investment, that· is, investment in the export and import replacement area contributing to solving the trade deficit. In more recent years, there has been a high proportion of investment in the non-tradeable goods area, such as office buildings, shopping complexes and the like-indeed, too much short-termism generally . The Treasurer should desist from misleading and inaccurate statements such as, 'We had poor-or no-investment in Australia 15 years prior to the Hawke Government' and recognise that the present mess the Australian economy is in is of his and the Government's own making. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the papers to which I referred earlier. Leave granted.

Speaker: Dr CHARLESWORTH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Perth) (7.57)One cannot help being amazed and overwhelmed by the hypocrisy of the Opposition. The shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), preached to us about education, when the previous Liberal Government left us with a retention rate of 36 per cent. In the time of this Government that has been improved to 58 per cent. The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) said that the Treasury has cooked the books. One can only be overwhelmed by the hypocrisy of those honourable members. The Economic Action Plan that we have all been hearing about for the last week is all about taking money from the bludgers and giving to the workers, in the words of John Elliott. But the document has no fiscal discipline. The area of most concern to me and to many in my electorate is the area in which, we are told, there are to be considerable savings-something like $800m. That money will be taken from those who presently receive unemployment benefits and have been long term unemployed. They wm no longer receive those benefits under the Opposition. One does not know what will happen to these people. It is to be assumed that immediately the benefit is taken away they will dissolve or disappear. It is impossiBassendean-Lockridge ble to know. If it were the ideological position of the Opposition that those who are long term unemployed should not receive a benefit, we could perhaps understand it. A philosophical stance would underpin the policy if the Opposition were to say that because these people will lose the benefit it would throw resources into retraining them, into providing training. But if we look at the Economic Action Plan we find that $200m-which could have been used to provide assistance for those people to get back into the work force-has been taken away from them. Unfortunately, the figures do not add up. Nearly half a million people are presently unemployed in this country. If we look at the Octob¥r figures in the Economic Roundup we see that there are only 65,000 job vacancies. If there are 65,000 job vacancies and 500,000 people are unemployed, even if the 65,000 vacancies could be taken, unfortunately a considerable number of people would remain unemployed and many of them would be long term unemployed. One of the best programs that the Government has developed-it has evolved over 10 years-is the Skillshare program. What do we find the Economic Action Plan saying about Skillshare? We find it saying that it will be phased out as soon as practicable. In my electorate there are five Skillshare programs. There is one in Midland and one in Morley-Bassendean, soon to be called the Lockridge Skillshare program. There is a program, called Employment 2000, situated in Morley, a program in Maylands and one in the city centre. They represent five Skillshare programs of the 354 all around the country providing for long term unemployed people, those who are most disadvantagedsingle mothers and people looking to get back into the work force-a route back into the work force. Those programs provide opportunities for training. They are efficient programs and are sponsored by groups comprising members of local councils, local business organisations, members of the union movement, members from technical and further education (T AFE) and members of all sorts of community groups. They all play a part in these Skillshare programs, which really work. The program in my electorate is one that we have fought for and whose funding was under threat. Over the last year 500 eligible people have gone through that program, 70 per cent of whom have ended up finding work or going back to the T AFE for tertiary education. What will the Opposition do? It will remove that program. I could understand that position if it were to remove the benefit but provide training for these people. But there is no decent or moral basis to justify what the Opposition is considering doing. It does not make sense. It does not add up. All the Opposition is saying to those very many people who have benefited from this program and worked in the program is, 'We don't care'. I can assure honourable members that over the next six months the people in my electorate and all over the country who work in those programs and who have benefited from them will tell the Opposition over and over again what they think of the Opposition.

text: Notwithstanding what the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) had to say, there is little doubt that the last two weeks have been a particularly bad period for the tired, out of touch, self-effacing, unethical Govern!flent opposite. We have seen it increasingly 1OcaI?a-!e .of matching the political impact and 10ltIatIves of our Economic Action Plan of 12 October. It has shown itself to be completely lost for fresh initiatives in the scandalous pilots dispute. In particular, it has been a disastrous period for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) whose wayward economic chickens appear to have come home to roost with a statistical venom matched only by his abuse and vitriol and t,he basic dishonesty he displayed in this place yesterday and today. First of all, the Septemb-r. current account deficit figure of $1.8 btlhon takes the three-month cumulative total for the first quarter of the financial year - o $6.1 billion against a full year projection 10 the Budget Papers of $18.5 billion. That means that we have seen one-third of that projected figure in the first quarter. Furthermore, that figure is over 50 per cent higher than for the same period last year. In other words, we are likely to see the current account deficit climb from $11.8 billion or 4 per cent of gross domestic product in 198788 to $17.4 billion or 5.2 per cent of GDP i- 1-88-89 to a figure approaching $24 bi!hon 10 the current financial year-in other words, closer to 6 per cent than the 5 per cent of GDP projected. So much for the Treasurer's - tatement in his Budget Speech that: . . . . to stabilise our international debt the current account deficit will have to continue to be reduced. The full force of this Government's resolve will be directed to this end. - learly, the Treasurer is yesterday's increas10gly desperate man and he is beginning to put into practical effect his banana republic perceptions of May 1986. Since May 1986, we have seen an improvement in the terms of trade by nearly 30 per cent, yet the current account deficit has increased from about $1.3 billion per month to $2 billion per month. The import penetration ratio has increased from 10 per cent in the March 1986 quarter to 13.5 per cent now, which is an increase of about 34 per cent. Our debt level has risen from $75 billion to $108 billion in net terms, and from $92 billion to $137 billion in gross terms. Our debt service burden has increased from about $700m per month to $1.2 billion per month; that is, from between 16 per cent and 18 per cent of exports to 32 per cent of exports. In other words, our debt service burden has doubled. Furthermore, in terms of the size of Australia's debt to commercial banks, it is now ranked third behind Brazil and Mexico and ahead of the Soviet Union and Argentina. Our credit rating has been downgraded twice by bot- international rating agencies, namely, Moody s and Standard and Poor's. Our prime interest rates have jumped from 18.25 per cent to over 20. per cent. Home loan interest rates have risen from 15.5 per cent to 17 or 18 per cent, which has been to the increasing detriment of the average mortgage carrying family. Finally, our inflation rate is still stuck at around 8 per cent, which is unquestioningly demonstrated by last Thursday's 2.3 per cent consumer price index number for September. The clear message from all of this is that Australia's economic problems are substantial and growing. The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) said last week: Today's inflation number was the acid test of the Keating-Kelty wages strategy and Keating has failed to deliver his part of the bargain, namely, inflation control. Demonstrably, Simon Crean got it right on Budget night when he said that he did not believe that the Budget did enough to. decrease inflation. The Treasurer can no longer rely on monetary policy as his principal policy adjustment instrument. He should stop juggling his increasingly unresponsive economic balls and he should refrain from any dishonest deal that promises wage increases but quickly - akes them back through inflation and higher 10terest rates. Government economic rhetoric and unsubstantiated abuse by the Treasurer in this place are simply not good enough. Mr Keating deserves our strongest condemnation.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: A great responsibility is placed on all honourable members who speak in this House, because they have the opportunity to raise issues that are of concern to their constituents without fear of legal recourse. However, this privilege places upon members the heavy responsibility to check their facts before making any statements that might harm the good name of people beyond these walls who are unable to properly defend themselves. Earlier this week the member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) made use of this privilege by repeating certain allegations that had been made against Ms Delia Lowe, the coordinator-administrator of the Jerringa local Aboriginal Land Council at Roseby Park near Nowra. I informed the member for Gilmore that I intended to make this speech this evening. I have known Delia Lowe for many years. During that time. I have helped to arrange many deputations that she has led to Canberra. Knowing her as I do, I was very surprised at the remarks that were made about her by the honourable member for· Gilmore. Ms Lowe enjoys a well earned rep- , utation for being a tireless worker for the Aboriginal cause. As such, she is respected by many people throughout Australia-both Aborigines and non-Aborigines alike. Indeed, she is well known overseas and has twice represented her people at the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Peoples. Two weeks ago, she was elected as one of the five State representatives of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Conservation Foundation. I would have hoped that the honourable member would have checked his facts before speaking. Obviously, he has failed to do that and has contented himself with making a number of ill-considered remarks that were based on false accusations that had been put to him by a few disgruntled members of that land· council. In order to protect the good name of Ms Lowe, let me present the facts. The annual general meeting of the Jerringa local Aboriginal Land Council was held on Monday, 16 October, in the Land Council's office at Roseby Park. In accordance with the regulations of the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Rights Act, notice of the meeting and the agenda were circulated seven days prior to the meeting. The first item on the agenda was the tabling of the auditor's report, which was done in the presence of the land council's accountant, who is a most reputable chartered accountant and a respected citizen of Nowra. According to the minutes of that meeting, the audit was accepted by a show of hands, with 23 people voting in favour and no-one voting against. At the meeting, Ms Lowe raised the question of continuing in the position as coordinator-administrator. For personal reasons she was not inclined to do so, partly because of other interests, partly because of her physical health, and partly because she realised there were a number of disgruntled persons within the community; but another member of the Council moved that she should continue in the position. This was put to the vote and was carried unanimously. As coordinator-administrator, Ms Lowe receives a wage which was set by the Land Council executive following consultations with the Department of Employment, Education and Training in accordance with Public Service guidelines. Mr Charles Perkins, who has been appointed by the Premier of New South Wales to inquire into the functioning of the New South Wales Land Rights Act, was asked to comment on this matter during an interview on radio 2ST while in Nowra last Monday. He replied that, under the Act, land councils certainly had the right to employ coordinators and administrators such as Ms Lowe, and to pay them a just wage. One of the most damaging remarks made by the honourable member was that Ms Lowe was reputed to be in receipt of unemployment benefit while in the paid employ of the Land Council. Let me once again put the record straight. Ms Lowe was in receipt of unemployment benefit for a period leading up to, but not extending beyond, June 1988 when the Jerringa local Aboriginal Land Council received fresh funding. Ms Lowe has been a paid employee of the Land Council since that date and has at no time since June 1988 received unemployment benefit. It is a great pity that the honourable member did not accord Ms Lowe the courtesy of checking the facts with her before repeating these wild and erroneous accusations. If he has any last lingering doubts he might care to check the facts with the Land Council's accountant. He might also care to contact the New South Wales Auditor-General who, under the terms of the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Rights Act, has the responsibility of ensuring that all land councils' books are properly kept and are correct. The honourable member has said he will ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to investigate his accusations. I will most certainly be forwarding to the Minister the details of this matter. I know that the honourable member is an honourable gentleman and I am sure that he will apologise to Ms Lowe. Question resolved in the affirmative.
